The Dutch team, led by Worthy De Jong, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter and won the game despite GB's comeback attempt in the last six minutes. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, noting his good stretch in the third quarter.

McGregor, the former five-weight world champion, submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a boxing match against Mayweather, who will be wearing 8oz gloves. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, will debate the use of lighter gloves on August 16. Lighter gloves offer less cushioning but can lead to more punishing punches. McGregor's team had previously inquired about the process of using lighter gloves. The NAC's primary concern is the health and safety of the fighters, and any deviation from regulations is subject to the chairman and commissioners' discretion. McGregor's boxing debut against Mayweather has faced criticism from boxing personalities, but Bennett, the NAC executive director, has several reasons to approve the fight, including McGregor's performance in the UFC and his victory over Diaz. Bennett also recommended hiring a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Joe Cortez. McGregor left his camp after reacting to images of him on the canvas

Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism, has seen its decline with the closure of the Dundee-based Sunday Post's London office. The street, known for its numerous bars and pubs filled with journalists, has transformed over the years. The departure of its last two journalists, Mr. Sherriff and Mr. Smith, marks the end of an era. The shift from traditional journalism to digital media and cheaper printing technology led to the relocation of most national newspapers. The buildings that once housed these newspapers have been repurposed, with the site of Mirror Group Newspapers now hosting Sainsbury's supermarkets. Despite the changes, the legacy of Fleet Street continues to inspire those with a passion for journalism and history.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, faced criticism and abusive comments on Twitter for her political donations and views. She donated £1m to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and to the Labour party in 2008. Rowling was called a traitor by some and blocked abusive users, whom she believed were SNP supporters. Despite the backlash, she engaged positively with other SNP supporters, finding common ground politically and humorously suggesting she would bring marshmallows to a hypothetical public book burning. The SNP won a significant majority in Scotland's recent election.

The Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and are more prone to violence. Poverty exacerbates the likelihood of young people offending, with poorer individuals more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Gender is a significant predictor of violence, with boys being three times more likely to engage in violent acts than girls. Despite a decrease in overall crime rates in Scotland, crime remains concentrated in deprived communities, raising questions about the effectiveness of the Scottish government's efforts to tackle inequality. The Scottish government, however, asserts that Scotland is becoming safer, with initiatives in place to address poverty and protect vulnerable populations.

Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Karl Haugh, who was stabbed in a Marian Estate laneway in Kilkee. Walsh, along with two other men, were arrested over the incident. The men were released without charge, but their files are being prepared for prosecution. During the altercation, weapons were used, and Haugh was pronounced dead at the hospital. The state presented evidence of tension in Kilkee due to the killing, leading to Walsh's remand in custody until August 14.

Phil Flanagan, an MLA, tweeted about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP, questioning the number of people Elliott harassed and shot during his service from 1982-1992. The tweet was deleted within an hour and an apology was issued, admitting the tweet was false. The High Court reserved judgment on compensation, and Flanagan's insurance firm refused to cover costs, leading to a separate court action. Elliott expressed disappointment at the delay but was satisfied with the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, with over 230 staff, has boosted sweater production due to strong sales of its branded range launched in January and growth in its private label business. The company, established in 1874, was acquired by managing director Benny Hartop last November. Production increased from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters weekly to meet demand. The firm sells in Europe and North America, with Mr. Hartop confident in the company's future success.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man, while she was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, denied causing serious injury through dangerous driving. He admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn, who is now in residential care. The incident occurred when Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light, despite traffic in the opposite direction having stopped. Wright claimed he was unable to see the traffic signal due to the sun's glare. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a Nato exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose" aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The German U-boat U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, is the focus of the exercise, attempting to evade detection by 10 Nato warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland. The exercise highlights a significant gap in Britain's defences, as the country no longer possesses its own maritime patrol aircraft. The search for Russian submarines is likened to finding a needle in a haystack due to the difficulty of detecting an invisible enemy underwater. The exercise serves as a reminder that some nations, like Britain, cannot conduct anti-submarine warfare alone and will need to address this vulnerability in the upcoming government defense and security review. Russia's increased military strength, with a fleet of around 60 submarines, is also noted, with the country leading in submarine development. The use of underwater unmanned vehicles (drones) and long-range maritime patrol aircraft are mentioned as

The passage discusses the escalating violence in South Sudan, particularly in the youngest country's southern Equatoria states. Since July, violence has spread from Juba, causing 340,000 people to flee into neighboring Uganda, surpassing the number of Syrian refugees in 2016. The violence, characterized by killing, rape, and targeting civilians along ethnic lines, has led to a significant refugee crisis. Nelson Ladu Thomas, a South Sudanese man, recounts the harrowing experiences of his family and others, including children being beaten and killed. The ethnic conflict began between Dinka President Salva Kiir and former Vice-President Riek Machar, a Nuer, with Equatorians becoming targets in July. Uganda, despite its generous response, is struggling to cope with the influx of refugees. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator emphasizes the need for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the massacre of civilians. The passage also highlights the resilience of refugees,

McKenzie, a 38-year-old professional boxer, will compete for the English super-middleweight championship against Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on November 12. He turned to boxing in 2013 after quitting football two years prior. With a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights, McKenzie is the son of Clinton, a former British and European champion, and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a three-time world champion.

The coalition's £330m investment includes £33m for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital, featuring 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities. The current 1813-built hospital is outdated and cramped, with the new facility expected to improve patient well-being. The project, led by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, aims for completion by autumn 2014, pending planning permission for the Bowers Lane site. The new hospital is part of a broader trend in Somerset, where three out of 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city center. The victim, a family member, was either in or near a black Mercedes car when shot. The incident occurred during a family gathering, with neighbors attempting to assist. This shooting is part of a recent spate of similar incidents in Sheffield, though none have been in the Upperthorpe area. Previous shootings have occurred in the city's north and have involved cases of mistaken identity.

The passage discusses the cyber warfare tactics used by various groups in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, hack into Russian servers and use DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites. They also monitor CCTV systems in rebel-held areas. Cyber Berkut, a group opposing Western influence, targets Ukrainian government websites and disrupts electronic systems. Anonymous International, known for publishing leaked documents, focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but also covers Ukraine. The passage highlights the use of hacking and information dissemination as tools in the ongoing conflict.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, and Duncan McNeil, a Labour MSP, both expressed emotional farewells as they stepped down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5 election. First Minister Alex Salmond, who served from 2007 to 2014, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to take on greater governance responsibilities. He welcomed the Scotland Bill's transfer of powers but criticized unionist politicians for not fulfilling their referendum pledges. Salmond also humorously acknowledged competition from the UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse champion chase. He concluded by highlighting the honor of serving Scotland and the public purpose of the parliament. McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster, particularly in accountability and scrutiny, and Annabel Goldie, a former Conservative MSP, humorously expressed her fondness for Finance Secretary John Swinney's outbursts.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will gather experiences of residential care from pensioners and their support networks to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review aims to assess the quality of life and care for older people in residential care, focusing on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care environment. The commissioner's team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The Care Forum Wales expresses disappointment that no care home provider expert is included on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for full sector engagement.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to over £100m. The company, which supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 shops in Scotland under the Country Store brand, saw international sales growth in Europe and new markets. Despite challenging times and the uncertainty of Brexit's impact, the board expressed confidence in the company's ability to navigate future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. A man in his 80s was also hospitalized. The police are treating the death as murder and are questioning 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, known as Ian John Baker. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying hair and average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked shirt. The investigation is ongoing, and residents are urged to report any information. Additional patrols are being conducted in the area.

David Lipton, IMF's second-in-command, highlighted risks in the global economy, noting a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. Weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, with a 25% drop in exports from the previous year, have led the IMF to consider downgrading its global growth forecast from 3.4% to an unspecified lower figure. This situation has ongoing implications for businesses and industries relying on China's growth narrative.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced a free crossing at Cowes until July 2nd due to issues with a new chain ferry, including breakdowns, running aground, and training problems. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspended the ferry for these reasons. Local businesses, particularly shopkeeper Angie Booth, are experiencing significant trade losses. Compensation for affected businesses and car damages is under discussion, with Ian Ward, a transport councillor, acknowledging the ferry's prototype status and teething problems, which have been addressed with ramp extensions and seamanship improvements.

A 32-year-old man died in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel in Bramshott at 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing the death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

Matching Models, an international temp agency in London, faced criticism for its job advertisements, which specified physical attributes such as a "classic look" and "b-c cup" for a personal assistant. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed these ads "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," prompting a call for clarification on their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners likened the ads to outdated 1970s standards. The founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the agency's focus on appearance for their high-profile clients, but faced backlash for perpetuating sexism. Employment lawyer James Lynas highlighted the potential for sex discrimination claims, as phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could be interpreted as ageist. The EHRC and employment law experts emphasized that such discriminatory practices are illegal under the 2010 Equality Act. Matching Models' clientele includes major brands, but the agency's approach to hiring has sparked debate on gender equality and

A shooting incident at a hostel connected to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore involved Mahesh, an office assistant, who allegedly shot two students, Gautami and Sirisha. The incident is rare in India, with strict gun control laws. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is remanded until April 12. A similar incident occurred in 2007 in Delhi.

Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 revealed 278 LGBT characters, with a rise in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The study also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president emphasized that while progress is being made, numbers alone don't tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down before a local party meeting where his candidacy faced opposition. The MP was previously criticized for a £10.25m public loan to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment, which is now under police investigation for financial irregularities. Despite his intention to run for re-election, he chose to resign, citing it as the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old man, fatally shot Jordan Edwards, a 15-year-old, with a rifle during a police response to a house party in Balch Springs, Dallas. The shooting occurred when officers believed they heard gunshots and Roy fired into a car full of teenagers. Oliver was subsequently fired from his job for policy violations and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. He faces a potential prison sentence of five to 99 years for murder. This case marks the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. Oliver is currently on bail.

The president-elect plans to move his family to Washington after his term, but has not set a date. The move has sparked criticism on social media, with some viewing it as a lack of commitment to the role of First Lady. However, the president-elect has emphasized that his wife, Melania Trump, and their son Barron will be his top priorities. The decision is not unprecedented, as there have been instances of school-age children living in the White House. The Obama family moved to Washington early to avoid their daughters having to change schools mid-term. The role of the First Lady is largely ceremonial, but some have taken on more active public roles. The White House can be adapted to the family's needs, with Chelsea Clinton performing some of her mother's duties during her father's presidency. The Obama family also prioritized family time, with daily dinners and strict rules about privacy. The president-elect has stated that living in the White House has made their family life more "normal" than ever.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness, leading to an investigation by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame. The initial police response to the man's call is under scrutiny by the COPFS. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report of the findings will be submitted to the COPFS later.

A yellow wind warning was issued due to gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), especially to the west of mountains, with an easterly direction potentially increasing impact. This led to travel disruptions in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, causing Telford Road to close for clean-up on Monday.

The Giants faced the Panthers with Derrick Walser starting short-handed, but the match was tied at 1-1 after Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal and Andy Bohmback equalized. Mike Radja then scored for the Giants, leading to a 4-2 score before Nottingham's David Ling scored a response. The teams will compete again in a double-header on Saturday, with Nottingham leading the league at 28 points.

Hamilton, starting from the back, suffered a broken front wing and five pit stops during the Chinese Grand Prix. Despite colliding with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, Sebastian Vettel finished second. Raikkonen managed to climb to fifth place. Hamilton, who had a 36-point deficit, struggled to catch up to Rosberg, who led the race. The race was marked by numerous collisions and the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton's car was damaged, affecting his performance. Mercedes chose to use soft tyres for the final stint, giving Hamilton an advantage. However, Hamilton still faced a challenging task to overtake Rosberg and secure the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, marking a significant moment in German football. His announcement was met with praise from former teammates, fellow players, and football administration figures. Hitzlsperger's courageous step is seen as a potential catalyst for addressing homophobia in the sport. Despite some controversy surrounding the issue, with former Germany captain Philipp Lahm expressing concerns in his autobiography, Hitzlsperger's decision is viewed as a positive step towards greater openness and acceptance of sexuality in German football. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and politician Volker Beck also expressed support for Hitzlsperger's announcement.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has contributed significantly to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League after 34 years, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract ending soon, he is seeking a new deal, aiming to help the team stay in the Premier League. Sidwell previously played for various Premier League teams and has been loaned to Brighton from Stoke. He believes he deserves another chance at the top level and is open to negotiations for a new contract.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended with a scoreless draw. Nathan Delfouneso and Jamille Matt provided Blackpool with early opportunities, but Colchester's Sam Slocombe made crucial saves. Despite equalizing from a corner and a header, Blackpool couldn't maintain the lead. Colchester's Sean Murray received a straight red card for violent conduct, reducing them to 10 men. The match ended with both teams scoring one goal each, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred and Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie each having close shots that were saved by the goalkeepers. The game was marked by several fouls and free kicks, but ultimately, neither team could secure a victory.

The 29-year-old player, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for Sky Blues in the previous season during which they were relegated from League One. He is set to debut for the U's in an EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester suffered a 3-1 defeat to Accrington at the start of the season. For the latest football transfers, refer to the dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament led to increased focus on creating a permanent memorial for police officers. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5 million for a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will honor over 1,400 fallen officers and staff. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes for personal remembrance, and the Home Secretary has pledged £1 million of the £4 million required. The project is expected to be finished by 2019.

Manchester United remains 15 points ahead of their nearest competitors with eight games left, following a 1-0 victory over Sunderland. Ferguson emphasizes the team's focus on upcoming matches, highlighting a record of 25 wins from the first 30 matches. Manchester United has a 15-point lead over Manchester City for the next league game, and despite injuries, the team is determined to win their next match. Changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, with the team's performance and determination being key factors in their success.

Google, under Mr. Schmidt's leadership, complied with UK tax laws legally, paying £10m in corporate taxes from 2006-2011. Schmidt views taxes as mandatory, not optional, and believes changes to the British tax system should be a political decision. He supports a new committee to oversee tax arrangements of major firms, allowing for transparency and fairness. Google, routing most UK sales through Ireland, is among multinationals criticized for minimizing UK tax payments. Schmidt advocates for international tax reform, suggesting corporate taxes should be based on economic activity and risk, not product consumption. He calls for politicians to set rules and for a constructive debate on a simpler tax system.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the agency bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year, following a £600m saving from a cap introduced in October. The cap limits hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services to paying no more than 55% above normal shift rates for agency staff, exempting only senior managers. Despite progress, the NHS is still short, with trusts 10% off target. The agency bill's decline is not yet reflected in other pay bill areas. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables on agency spending and collect data on high earners from agency work. Examples of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates for doctors were found. NHS Improvement's CEO emphasizes the need for further action to reduce agency staff costs.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic prosperity, has suffered due to the country's economic crash. However, local traders, like Matt O'Brien, are witnessing a slow recovery with increased business and diversification into new areas such as children's wear and dress hire. Despite this, the main opposition party criticizes the government's investment strategy, particularly the delayed implementation of water meters and lack of foreign direct investment. The government, however, is optimistic about the upcoming tourism development by Center Parcs, which could create jobs and attract tourists. Nevertheless, traders like O'Brien believe more efforts, such as free parking, are needed to further boost the local economy.

The cricket tournament concludes on May 29th, with eight teams competing in a double round-robin format. The top four teams advance to the play-offs. The tournament features England players Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The fixtures and results are available on BBC Sport. Key statistics include Warner's highest score of 294, Kohli's 267 runs, De Villiers' 249, and De Kock's highest innings score of 108. The leading wicket-takers are McClenaghan with 9, Kumar with 8, and Rahman with 7. The schedule includes matches on various dates, with the final match on May 29th.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, with many being non-recyclable and ending up in landfills and waterways. To combat this, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, following the success of similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, which have led to reduced usage and potential environmental benefits.

A school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, and hundreds of homes in Wales faced power cuts due to strong winds. Train services experienced delays and speed restrictions, and Irish Ferries cancelled six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed two properties in Wrexham. The A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge restrictions were lifted, but the Boxing Day Dip in Denbighshire was postponed due to the forecast.

The actor expresses excitement about a new project, reuniting with director Ryan Coogler and working with stars like Lupita Nyong'o, who won an Oscar for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, known for Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The film, set for a February 2018 release, is a reboot of Fantastic Four, with Jordan reprising his role as the Human Torch. Nyong'o will also appear, having played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The actor did not specify his role in the new project.

The Alexandra Palace theatre, established in 1875, is set for refurbishment to host a variety of events including theatrical performances, cinema, comedy, and live music. The project, costing £26.6m, includes repairs to BBC studios and public space creation in the glazed east court. Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and the Alexandra Palace Charitable Trust (£1m), the goal is to reopen the theatre in 2018 as part of a larger east wing restoration. Despite years of disuse, the theatre retains much of its original decor and stage equipment.

The passage discusses a former Manchester City player who has represented England 61 times since his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed his wish for the team's future success under Sam Allardyce.

Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire that engulfed the entire structure, including their dog and cats. The fire was caused by rubbish burned in the wood stove, a mistake Mrs. Smith had made many times before. The family escaped due to their son David, who was awake and alerted them via FaceTime. Despite wearing only pyjamas, they survived thanks to the community's support in donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith emphasized the importance of David's quick thinking in saving the family.

The Premier League club West Ham, owned by Sullivan and Gold with over 85% stake since 2010, is being considered for a £200m offer by an energy drinks giant. Previously, they considered selling a minority shareholding to manage debts but aimed to pass ownership to their children. West Ham has also been linked with potential takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium.

The red carpet event featured fan-voted awards and served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, with Shailene Woodley receiving additional accolades. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep received awards for their roles in 22 Jump Street and Into the Woods, respectively. Kevin Hart and Robert Downey Jr. were recognized for their comedic performances. The event previewed upcoming films like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron.

Cammy Smith, 21, was loaned from Dons to United in July and has scored five goals this season. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday. Jack Ross, St Mirren's boss, considers Smith a valuable acquisition and a good fit for the team's attacking options.

Northumberland County Council plans to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months using Jetpatcher machines, as the weather warms up. Additionally, extra staff will repair damaged drainage systems and clear gutters affected by heavy rain.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuests's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). Following the incident, EnQuest took additional precautionary measures to prevent future exposure. The rigging supervisor, Steve Innes, expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects and the company's duty of care. EnQuest and Wood Group prioritized employee safety, with Wood Group conducting medical assessments and reinforcing health and safety procedures. The HSE was informed but did not conduct an investigation as the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR. Unite union criticized the handling of the incident, emphasizing the need for transparency to ensure a safer working environment.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) returned a sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari after it was revealed that the artwork, bought for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, was potentially stolen Indian antiquities. The dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, confessed to dealing in looted items. The sculpture was thought to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) requested its return, and ACM plans to pursue legal action for compensation. Out of 30 objects purchased from Art of the Past, none are confirmed as stolen, but the ASI was permitted to view them.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake occurred 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in Milan and Florence, with no immediate injuries or damage reported. Italy, prone to earthquakes, experienced a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009, which resulted in 300 deaths. The quake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) with its epicenter in Garfagnana, causing power outages and prompting school evacuations. Several aftershocks were felt, and the area is still recovering from previous quakes. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted for providing inaccurate information before the 2009 quake, which led to many fatalities. The recent quake was described as a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" event by INGV's Alessandro Amato.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, initially doubted South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit. However, he observed positive results, expressing joy upon seeing the fruit still attached to the plant, indicating it was not yet ripe for consumption.

Rockstar delayed the release of their open world adventure game, originally set for 27 January, until 24 March to allow for additional testing and polishing. The company emphasized that this decision was made in the best interest of the game and fans. Meanwhile, online heists are being added to consoles before the PC release. The PC version of GTA V will feature high-resolution visuals and support for triple monitor setups. The game, which became the fastest-selling entertainment product in history, has minimum PC specifications published for players to prepare their systems.

A 76-year-old artist, Simpson, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting, which depicts medieval leper holes, was one of several in a series and was entered due to its familiarity and size. Simpson, who has been longlisted four times, plans to use the prize money for art supplies. The judges praised the work for its subtlety and emotional depth, with one likening it to a "tone poem." The prize, established in 1957, has seen previous winners like David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building and Yeni Akit offices in Istanbul, with no casualties reported. The attackers shattered windows and left spent bullet casings at both locations. Police cordoned off the area and are investigating, while no group has claimed responsibility. Similar night-time attacks occurred almost simultaneously, with the Hurriyet offices being targeted previously. Both newspapers support President Erdogan's AK Party.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer starting 1 January. The player, who scored three goals in 23 appearances during a loan at Crawley, will become Bignot's first signing.

Southgate, 46, is being considered for a permanent England manager role after a successful tenure as interim manager, overseeing wins and draws. He has a World Cup qualifier and a friendly match to prove his competency. Wenger, Arsenal's manager, supports his competency and long-term future at the club. Hector Bellerin, a 21-year-old defender, is also set to receive a new contract from Arsenal, despite interest from other clubs. Aaron Ramsey, a midfielder, is expected to miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 1:45 PM GMT on Thursday. The incident is being investigated jointly by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with Fruehauf fully cooperating in the investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats. The RMT union had previously claimed workers were paid below the national minimum wage. The change will revert contracted services to Serco Northlink, which had previously operated the vessels. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap but was declined by Seatruck. The new arrangements, which will ensure minimum wage compliance, are set to begin early next month, pending finalization of financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink, awarded a six-year contract in 2012, operates subsidized ferries and cargo boats to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died six days after an altercation at Rockley Park in Poole, where Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and with his mother Samantha, admitted to perverting the course of justice by lying about the events. The court heard they were in a "down phase" and got intoxicated at the park bar, leading to a confrontation. The pair will face sentencing on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known as "The Invisible Man," passed away at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He was a key contributor to Michael Jackson's success, penning hits like "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Baby Be Mine." Temperton's work extended to other artists and earned him a Grammy in 1990. His influence and talent were widely recognized, with tributes from industry peers and fans. His family requested privacy during this time.

Researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Amazonian rainforest. The findings, which include over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs," were initially hidden by bamboo-dominated vegetation. The purpose of these sites remains unclear, as they lack defensive features and few artefacts were found. The researchers suggest the geoglyphs were constructed amidst taller vegetation, making them less visible above the forest canopy. This contrasts with other ritual sites like the Maya pyramids. Soil analysis indicates the Amazonian forests were not pristine but were shaped by humans over 6,000 years, with a focus on economically valuable trees. The researchers propose these ancient practices may have influenced the biodiversity of Acre's forests, hinting at a "prehistoric supermarket" of forest products.

Australian player, ranked 12th in the world, Kyrgios won the Japan Open and is nearing the top 10. He lost to Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes, attributing his lack of vocal energy to feeling tired and the physical toll of traveling from Shanghai to the Qi Zhong Stadium. Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a previous outburst at the Shanghai Masters.

Scientists and charities advocate for the HPV vaccine to protect against head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger individuals, particularly men. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering expanding the vaccination program, which currently targets girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer. The vaccine is also suggested to benefit boys, as HPV is responsible for 5% of global cancer cases. The Welsh government's decision is pending the committee's recommendations.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Calder High School, was battling gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare blood cancer. Despite his illness, Jak attended a school prom in his honor for 10 minutes before feeling unwell. His mother, Allison, announced his death on his Facebook page, Jak's Journey, which had over 28,000 Likes. Jak's positive attitude and his story of fighting cancer inspired many. He received recognition for his resilience, including the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Jak's family continued to share his life and treatment updates on the page, which also featured his love for Rangers FC and interactions with football stars. After learning his cancer had spread, Jak chose not to pursue further treatment, focusing on making the most of his remaining time. His family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and Jak's final days included visits to the Kelpies, a romantic meal with his girlfriend, and a special football match fundraiser.

In a match between Egypt and Uganda, Egypt won 1-0 with a goal from Abdallah El Said. The game was initially dull, with neither team creating many chances. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt's Mohamed Salah played a key role in the match, assisting El Said's goal. Uganda, however, struggled to score despite several set-piece opportunities. Egypt's Essam El Hadary was tested by Uganda's veteran players but failed to register a shot on target. The match ended with Egypt advancing to play Ghana, while Uganda's hopes of qualifying were dashed. The match was marked by offside calls and fouls, with Egypt's Mohamed Shafy and Amr Warda also making notable contributions.

Lancashire County Council plans to acquire land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, following a comparative study by Network Rail. The council aims to establish a new railway station in Skelmersdale, which currently lacks its own station, to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The chosen site is large enough for potential future expansion and offers good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The council will initiate the land acquisition process. Skelmersdale was designated a new town in 1961 and is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without a railway station.
A man in his late 40s was arrested after police discovered an elaborate grow house containing plants in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old unidentified woman of Kurdish origin was found severely injured on a Hamelin pavement after being dragged through streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, was arrested and is now in custody. The motive behind the attack remains unclear. The area has been secured and witnesses are being sought.

The study by Cass Business School and other universities found that women are as likely as men to request a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The research, which compared like-for-like full-time male and female workers, revealed men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also debunked the theory that women are less likely to ask for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from stereotypes. Factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications were considered. The findings suggest some level of discrimination against women in pay negotiations. However, younger women are negotiating their pay more successfully than older females, indicating a potential shift in negotiation behavior. The study, based on Australian workplace data, is unique in systematically recording pay raise requests and reasons.

Oxford City Council has conducted ground investigations for new burial sites but found none suitable. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, will be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council is still exploring options despite running out of suitable land within Oxford. All council-owned sites identified have been discounted due to various reasons. Once the cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible. The last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from July 19-22 in Stornoway, offers an augmented reality app that allows global visitors to access online information about signs, posters, videos, and band interviews. The app, developed by HebCelt, enhances the festival experience and enables interaction with the event's atmosphere at any time. The app also provides updates on the festival, including information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the unique festival experience.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse, Many Clouds, had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed Many Clouds suffered from a rare "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." The incident has prompted the sport to investigate the causes of such symptoms and potential preventive measures. Many Clouds had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and despite his tendency to overheat, his welfare was closely monitored. The report concludes that his death was due to a rare haemorrhage, not linked to his known condition of overheating.

A 15-year-old girl was charged with rape after meeting David Ayrton, a man with learning difficulties, in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Davina, now 34, denied the charge and was remanded into custody by Judge Ian Pearson, with a likely prison sentence in a male facility in Winchester. Ayrton, who attempted suicide the previous summer, disclosed his sexuality during the trial but denied physical alterations or medication. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's, recalled the events clearly. Ayrton confessed to the attack in 2014 to a care home worker. Protocols were established for her detention at the prison.

Serbs Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares defeated World number one Djokovic 6-4 6-4 in Rio. Djokovic, despite being a 12-time Grand Slam winner and having won his 30th Masters title in Toronto, suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July to American Sam Querrey. The passage also mentions that Djokovic came back to claim his 30th Masters title before the Olympics.

Over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms on Saturday. The event, where only chainsaws are allowed, challenges competitors to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Pete Bowsher, the previous year's winner from Moffat, will defend his Claymore Trophy title.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player who has been out due to a foot injury, is nearing a return to play. He is currently in a pre-season phase to regain fitness before the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay in his home region despite offers elsewhere. He plans to return to play for Wales and the Ospreys, prioritizing his national team commitments. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins with a match against Ireland on February 7.

Two men carrying backpacks were intercepted by US border agents near Sumas, Washington, attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested, while Nathan Hall, a Canadian citizen, was also apprehended. The backpacks contained a California driver's license with a picture of Hall but a name of William Nickerson. Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to pick up the men and transport the drugs, with Lambert allegedly receiving $11,000 for the task. The incident highlights the ongoing issue of drug and firearms smuggling through a known route near the border. The three defendants face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling sessions for children facing online abuse, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity highlighted the distressing experiences of children as young as seven, who faced torment, abuse, and fear of attending school due to cyberbullying. Dame Esther Rantzen emphasized the need for adult intervention and serious attention from schools to address the issue. The Anti-Bullying Week aims to combat this problem through collaboration with parents, schools, and organizations. Young individuals seeking help advised parents to understand their emotional distress and seek support rather than resorting to self-harm or disengagement.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office requested a postponement of a vote on authorizing new homes in Israeli settlements Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, to avoid further tension with the US ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction, which Netanyahu accused the White House of influencing. The resolution, which Israel rejected, stated that settlement establishment violates international law and hinders a two-state solution. The move to postpone the vote was also seen as a strategic move to prevent political voting in Jerusalem, which Israel considers part of its capital. The Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution, hoping it would facilitate a peace conference in France.

The Queen celebrated her 90th birthday, with Prince William praising her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. The Queen's visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office marked the 500th anniversary of the postal service. The Queen and Prince Philip walked around Windsor to unveil The Queen's Walkway, a 6.3km self-guided trail. The Queen's birthday was also marked by the release of ten stamps featuring the Royal Family. The BBC interviewed Prince William, who acknowledged criticism but emphasized his commitment to royal duty. The Queen's birthday was criticized by Republic, a pressure group, for excessive coverage.

Cheltenham Town and West Ham United played a match where West Ham United dominated, scoring two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Despite Cheltenham's efforts, including a low volley from Harry Pell and a header from Jordon Forster, they couldn't find the net. West Ham United made seven changes from their previous losses, with key substitutions and free kicks contributing to their victory. The match ended with a scoreline of 0-2 in favor of West Ham United, marking the end of League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision involving Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig. Werner failed to see a motorcyclist turning right, leading to the fatal crash on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000, with a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family expressed no desire for Werner to be imprisoned, acknowledging it was a momentary mistake. Werner showed remorse but could not explain the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British fighter from Syria, is facing a potential life sentence for his involvement in the conflict. Known as Abu Daigham al-Britani, he was part of the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed, which produced propaganda targeting young British Muslims. Khawaja returned to the UK in June, after faking his own death online, and was apprehended at Dover. He is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria. Khawaja's cousin, Tahir Bhatti, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja admitted four offences, and an additional charge of soliciting to murder is on file. He was held in the high-risk terrorism suspects unit at Belmarsh prison while on remand. The Metropolitan Police's counter-terrorism command described him as a man who chose the path of terrorism. The exact reasons for his return and his plans remain unknown.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish eighth in the table. He is set to join Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season, with a view to fit well into their playing style. Despite a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season, Jackson has declined it. Barnsley will compete in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

National Trust volunteers are clearing sealed bottles washed up on Cornwall's coast, which are believed to pose a risk to wildlife. The bottles are thought to have come from a container that went overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there's no evidence linking the bottles to the MV Blue Ocean's lost container. The Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact on marine life. The public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them. Monitoring of affected beaches is underway by the National Trust and partners.

A road incident on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 2:00 PM resulted in several people sustaining minor injuries. The road closure necessitated the implementation of diversions through the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is conducting ongoing investigations into the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances in the previous season, contributing to Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and their promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has played 83 times in all competitions. Following their promotion, Dervite, along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, signed new contracts with Bolton.

The Lib Dem Lord Oates and Baroness Smith criticized Labour for being ready to concede everything and for giving false hope to people concerned about their future in Britain. Despite previously cooperating to defeat government proposals on EU citizens' rights and Brexit, tensions arose when Labour deferred to the Commons, leading to accusations of grandstanding and false hope-building by the Lib Dems. The Labour source described the Lib Dems' actions as unforgivable, while Baroness Ludford defended the Lib Dems' stance against Labour's perceived compliance with the Conservatives' hard Brexit agenda. Despite past alliances on various issues, the Labour source predicted ongoing tensions and a lack of demand for further cooperation. Both parties, however, expressed a willingness to continue working together on shared issues.

The passage discusses the low priority of defence in the current election, with most political parties not focusing on it. Defence is ranked low in public concern, with significant cuts to the UK's armed forces. The UK has fallen in defence spending rankings and is unlikely to meet the 2% GDP target. The military is facing capability gaps and potential further cuts. The Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing the nuclear deterrent, while Labour and the Lib Dems have different approaches. The Royal Navy faces challenges in crewing new aircraft carriers and equipping them with the F-35 jet. The passage highlights the need for a Strategic Defence Review to address these issues.

Barcelona, despite facing investigations into the Neymar transfer, insists they have not committed any tax-related offenses. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, but the total cost, including signing-on fees, wages, and agents' fees, is estimated at £106.8m. Barcelona has made a tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential interpretations of their fiscal obligations. The club's president, Sandro Rosell, is under investigation but denies wrongdoing. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season. The case's outcome remains uncertain.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, tragically lost his life when a Mazda Premacy, driven by Albert Kenneth Newman in the wrong direction on a motorway, collided with his van. The incident occurred near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for older individuals, citing the natural decline in reaction times with age. They suggest a practical driving test with an instructor to assess driving abilities. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) currently requires drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years without a medical or driving test. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to drive safely for as long as possible. The family of Luciw mourns the loss of a kind-hearted man who was looking forward to witnessing his baby girl's first crawl. The accident has left a lasting impact on those involved, with calls for better safety measures for older drivers.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, following reports of debilitating side effects experienced by some women. Two patients resigned from the original review group due to dissatisfaction with a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton from Glasgow Caledonian University will examine the final report's process and lessons for the future. The report advises against routine offering of procedures to women with pelvic organ prolapse, recommends a range of treatments and informed patient choices, and mandates reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government lacks the power to do so, and the chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, acknowledged the difficulty in achieving consensus. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, who suffered complications, also resigned, and a consultant quit the expert group over concerns about the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh implants, with more than 400 taking legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, a Scottish runner, broke McColgan's 25-year-old British record for the 5K race by 14 seconds, finishing in 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially questioned the legitimacy of the record-breaking attempt due to concerns about the race's criteria and the absence of doping control. However, British Athletics confirmed the time would be officially ratified. McColgan acknowledged Muir's potential for world medals, noting that Muir's time of 14.49 seconds is impressive for a 3.55-minute 1,500m runner. McColgan compared Muir's race to her own record-breaking experience 25 years ago, and praised Muir's talent, suggesting she has the potential to improve her time to 14.30 seconds.

William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist and former world number one, competed in the Rio Olympics after a coma-inducing fall. Despite a faultless performance in the show-jumping phase, his medal chances were ruined by time penalties in the cross-country phase. He finished 12th overall, with France's Astier Nicolas taking silver and American Phillip Dutton securing bronze. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions the opportunity to meet and ride a mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Olympics.

Murray, a Briton, won a tennis match against Fognini, the 29th seed, with scores of 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. The match was tense and had moments of doubt, but Murray managed to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Fognini had a chance to force a fifth set but Murray won five consecutive games. Johanna Konta, another Briton, also advanced to the second week for the first time with a win over Maria Sakkari. The match took place in dark conditions, which could have affected the players' performance. Murray expressed relief and satisfaction with his performance, looking forward to improving his game for the next match against Frenchman Benoit Paire.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014. The bar served alcohol until 4:49 BST, violating licensing hours. The judge ordered a three-month closure and charged Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, had a poor record and was fined £3,000, while Thomas received a £1,000 fine. The defense highlighted lax adherence to licensing laws and improper management of the premises.

Mike Nesbitt, speaking at the launch of the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination. The party aims to use the upcoming election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal. Nesbitt reassured that his comments about potential vote transfers were not regretted, and he encouraged voters to support candidates who will act in their community's best interest. He expressed confidence in his position and the diversity of stances among his party's candidates. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' outlines various policy proposals, including tackling waiting lists, increasing police numbers, and addressing issues related to Brexit. Nesbitt also highlighted the need for accountability in Stormont, criticizing incompetence, arrogance, and corruption. Despite controversy over his remarks, Nesbitt remains focused on the election's outcome and the possibility of a coalition with the SDLP.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced a motion for the assembly's approval to align Northern Ireland with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', the law will allow posthumous pardons and enable living gay and bisexual men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion aims for equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales. The motion will be considered by the assembly.

Yvonne Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a Scottish 1500m race, setting a new record of 4:19.12 seconds. This achievement surpassed her previous record of 4:22.60 from 1994 and placed her second on the British all-time list. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record, is now training for the British trials in Birmingham, aiming for an Olympic spot in Rio. She began her season with an 800m victory in France and will compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir balances her training with her veterinary studies, having completed her fourth year of vet school.

The passage highlights a selection of pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland, which have been ranked as the "most excellent" in terms of water quality. The core information focuses on these beaches' superior water quality.

The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, concluded that the Russian state likely sponsored the plot to poison Alexander Litvinenko, a former Soviet officer who defected to the UK in 2000. Litvinenko died from polonium-210 poisoning in 2006, and the evidence suggests Russian state involvement. However, Horwell clarified that this did not implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin directly. The suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, left a "trail of polonium" and had no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. Despite the force's desire to try them for murder, extradition attempts have failed, and they remain in Russia. The inquiry was adjourned for further discussion.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed captain of the Australian Twenty20 team in Aaron Finch's absence due to injury. David Warner, 28, becomes Smith's vice-captain. Smith, who has captained the side in three Tests and played 32 Tests for Australia, has an average of 54.66. Clarke, 34, retires after a heavy Ashes defeat. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in upcoming limited-overs matches.

Mr. Farron, leader of a liberal party, is passionate about LGBT-plus rights and aims to prioritize equal marriage and extend marital rights to transgender individuals. He refused to directly address whether he considers homosexual sex a sin but stated that he believes everyone is a sinner. He voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, despite supporting equality and not directly answering what those concerns were. The bill's defeat led to his vote against it, and he highlighted the issue of the spousal veto affecting transgender people's access to marriage.

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare plans to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, potentially re-employing many former Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to positively impact the local economy and strengthen Newcastle's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical industry player, currently distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is departing from his role as the former interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive at the local authority on Friday, marking the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are also leaving through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn criticizes the council for losing senior staff and predicts more departures. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, acknowledges the dedication and professionalism of the departing trio.

English rider Martin quit road racing on Hondas for the year due to mechanical issues and a crash at the TT. He clarified on Facebook that he's not giving up racing but won't compete on Honda bikes. He also won't race at the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin expressed dissatisfaction with the TT experience and plans to focus on classics and unconventional races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This loss is the biggest since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29, after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline is evident in their loss of key northern states and control of Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. Despite this, the PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's historic gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to secure a national spread of votes. The elections were not held in seven states, and there were 66 reported violent incidents. The PDP will need to introspect and rebuild under a new leader after 16 years in power.

The Mighty environmental lobby group accused Olam and Temasek, Singapore's state-owned investment company, of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to the haze in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and has vowed to remove non-compliant suppliers. Temasek, as Olam's majority stakeholder, has dismissed the allegations, stating that they support no-burn policies and proper governance. The palm oil industry, worth $88bn by 2022, faces accusations of environmental harm and deforestation, with activists calling for stricter enforcement. Olam also faces criticism in Gabon for clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations, but it claims its operations are responsible and transparent.
The restaurant started offering puppy platters on August 27, 2016, following a new law permitting dogs to dine outdoors. The clip showcases this unique dining experience for dogs.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee issue, having only played from the bench in recent games. Derby County's David Nugent, who missed a game due to a groin injury, may return. Jacob Butterfield, a midfielder, is seeking a recall after scoring a late goal from the bench against the Terriers.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The ban was initially imposed due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." YouTube has a process for blocking offending material upon request from the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA). However, Google requires a thorough review before restricting access to content deemed illegal in a country. Activists are calling for greater transparency in the terms agreed between Google and the government. YouTube's spokesperson confirmed that government requests for content removal are recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban's lifting was welcomed by many young Pakistanis.

Domenico Scala, a Swiss-Italian member of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, withdrew from the 2015 elections due to a potential conflict of interest with Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter. However, Andreas Bantel, Scala's spokesman, argues that nationality alone does not constitute a conflict of interest. The upcoming election to replace Blatter, scheduled in Zurich, will feature five candidates without an incumbent president, eliminating any potential conflict. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), has threatened legal action if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing the importance of fairness and integrity in the electoral process. The outcome of this dispute remains uncertain.

Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56) were killed at Harford Attachments in a paint-spraying area. A flashover explosion, due to toxic fume build-up and ignition, caused a fire-ball effect. Forensic inquiries and witness statements are being collected. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence with inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia was on the verge of expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) but later apologized, restoring their participation. Morocco, previously replaced as hosts for the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), reducing their fine from $1m to $50,000. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) clarified that they never accused CAF or the Mauritian referee of corruption, but rather criticized the referee's choice and handling of the match. A meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou helped resolve the dispute, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia will compete in Group A, while Morocco will be in Group F. Tunisia's participation ensures they could potentially reach their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup finals.

In a 95th-minute incident at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1 against City. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho from City were sent off for violent conduct, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban and Fernandinho a three-match ban. Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas was not penalized further. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for the incident. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses the challenges in diagnosing cancer due to the lack of specific symptoms, with a focus on a study in Wales. The study, conducted by Bwrdd Iechyd Cwm Taf, found that 40% of patients in the Cwm Taf area had no identifiable symptoms at diagnosis. The study also highlighted the importance of early detection and the potential for improved outcomes with early diagnosis. The researchers emphasized the need for further research and better diagnostic tools. The study's findings have implications for cancer screening and early detection strategies in Wales.

England secured a victory at Old Trafford, leveling the series against Pakistan with a day to spare. England's Joe Root scored 254 and 71 not out, taking four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan struggled on the pitch, batting for only 63 and 70 overs in the first two innings. England's performance was praised for its quality and discipline, with England expected to win again. The series is predicted to be tight, with Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq being the only players to score over 50 runs in the first two Tests. Pakistan expressed disappointment and a need for mental strength and improved shot selection.

Warren Gatland, the head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has appointed Rob Howley as an interim coach and McBryde as the forwards coach for the third time. McBryde, who has led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013, sees this as an exciting opportunity to lead the team again. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches for the summer tour. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes Welsh coaches' involvement will benefit Welsh rugby in the long term. The Lions' tour to New Zealand is expected to provide a challenging test for the team.

Hull City, struggling with injuries and a slump in form, lost their sixth-minute penalty to Southampton, which led to a frustrating start for the home team. However, the mood changed in the second half when substitute Robert Snodgrass scored his fourth league goal of the season, and Michael Dawson headed in a free-kick. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull City's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves. In the final minute of added time, Clucas produced a remarkable goalline clearance, securing a 2-1 victory for Hull City. This win ended Hull's six-game losing streak and their position in the bottom three of the league. The team's resilience and Snodgrass's performance were highlights of the match.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision on the B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa, at approximately 2:15 PM BST. The tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have closed the B1191 between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction and are seeking witnesses. The deceased motorcyclist was a local resident, with no further details disclosed.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into alleged abuse of power following covert recordings, aiming to end political turmoil before June elections. His decision was criticized by opposition leader Zoran Zaev and EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it could jeopardize Macedonia's EU membership. The controversy began with recordings suggesting vote-rigging, a murder cover-up, and high-level government corruption, with Zaev accusing the government of wiretapping and illegal activities. The government denies these claims and accuses Zaev of destabilization.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea, having been promoted in 2011, are considering appointing new manager Paul Clement to avoid potential relegation. The club has faced challenges since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with frequent management changes and player losses. Despite these issues, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League, emphasizing the club's history and importance to the local area.

Leyton Orient, after reaching League One in 2010, needed a win to maintain their play-off hopes. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal for Dagenham & Redbridge, relegating Orient. Dagenham, under manager John Still, returned to the National League after a first-time promotion in 2007. Orient has the worst goal difference in League Two and conceded more goals this season than last. Still, in his third stint, is committed to helping Orient gain promotion next season. The loss of two managers in a season has been challenging, but Still emphasizes the importance of professionalism and winning games for play-off chances. Dagenham's lack of organization and discipline was highlighted as reasons for their relegation.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, at 36, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Klopp describes the appointment as "wonderful news" and acknowledges Gerrard's readiness to learn and become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who won multiple trophies with Liverpool and later joined LA Galaxy, is also working towards his UEFA A coaching licence to manage in the Premier League. Despite being linked with the managerial role at MK Dons, Gerrard felt the opportunity came too soon for him.

McManus scored early for the hosts, with a close-range goal and a deflected strike by Ross Forbes increasing the lead. Kyle McAusland's shot brought Alloa back into play, but the hosts maintained their advantage with another goal from McManus and a late one from Denny Johnstone, securing a comfortable victory.

Ofsted discovered children being taught in poor conditions in three Birmingham locations, leading to their closure. Illegal school operators could face up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is considering stricter regulation for places teaching children for more than 6-8 hours a week. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Midlands' Muslim communities, were inspected. Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed concern that these cases may only be the beginning, with potential risks of abuse and radicalization. The government has funded six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, with the Education Secretary authorizing prosecutions for unregistered schools. The consultation on further regulation is ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh, is set to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. The distillery, led by Kate Macinnes, aims to establish the Scottish Borders as a hub of distilling excellence. Despite having one of the smallest production stills in the UK and fitting entirely within a cowshed, the distillery's focus is on producing a gin that captures the local flavor and terroir. The gin's name honors Lilliard, a legendary figure from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery's commitment to local sourcing aligns with the ethos of the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site. The opening of Lilliard Gin is anticipated with excitement by John Henderson of Born in the Borders.

Gary Green, 51, was convicted of causing Harry Whitlam's death by driving under the influence on private land in August 2013. Green, who was found to be over twice the legal alcohol limit, backed his tractor into Whitlam, resulting in a 16-month and two-week prison sentence. The incident occurred at Swithens Farm near Leeds, and Green's actions were deemed "reckless" by HSE inspector Julian Franklin. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and hope for her family to remember the good times they shared with Harry, despite the tragedy. The court process was completed, and the family continues to miss Harry deeply.

Luis Suarez, Uruguay striker, has been allowed to train and participate in friendly matches after an appeal against a four-month ban was rejected. The Cas ruling confirmed Fifa's sanctions but deemed the ban excessive, as it prevented Suarez from training. He can now train with Barcelona, attend matches, and engage in promotional activities. Suarez's legal team argued Fifa misapplied its rules, and the Uruguayan player must serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international matches. The World Players' Union expressed disappointment with the court's decision, which they believe is disproportionate to Suarez's violation of Fifa's disciplinary code. The ruling considers the club's interests and emphasizes that sanctions should be proportionate, with different considerations for repeat offenders.

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a unique athletics race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, steep slopes, and water pistols. Participants could carry any combination of men, women, or both. Blake-Smith and Anna's victory, achieved through a week of preparation, led to their participation in the World Championships in Finland in July.
