With 22 medals to her name, Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, having won 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze in cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has secured 21 world titles in both sports. Storey switched from swimming to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, facing financial difficulties, failed to meet the extended deadline to pay their football creditors, leading to their expulsion from the Football Conference. The club's debt, including unpaid wages and tax demands, amounted to approximately £225,000. Despite fundraising efforts and offers from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1, the club's financial issues persisted. The Hereford Bulls' situation worsened due to falling gate attendance since their relegation from League Two in 2012. The Hereford Bulls' fate was sealed when they failed to meet the final deadline, leading to their expulsion and Chester City's promotion to the Conference Premier.

The passage discusses a former Manchester City player who has represented England in 61 senior matches since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed his wish for the team's future success.

Christopher Hogwood, a key figure in the early-music movement, passed away after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years, producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His recordings, such as the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, were highly acclaimed. Hogwood's academic background included studies at Cambridge University and he held various positions in music organizations. His death was mourned by colleagues who praised his generosity, influence, and the lasting impact of his work on future generations of musicians. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected due to his family's concerns, has been removed from mainstream schooling as he struggles to cope. His parents are seeking a place at a special school, but all options in the South Eastern Education Board area are full. The family's situation has raised concerns about the capacity of special needs schools, with the Education Authority reviewing the need for such places and aiming to provide them near the children's residences. An extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local school, offering hope for the boy's placement in the near future. However, the family's privacy concerns prevent the Education Authority from commenting on their specific case.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) plans to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, a tenant at Rodney Parade stadium. County, who have a lease until 2023, are protected under their current agreements, which also include Newport Squash Club. The WRU's takeover will be voted on May 9. County, currently two points clear of relegation, could secure survival if they win their next game. Relegation would be a significant setback for both fans and the city of Newport. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules.

The passage recounts the experiences of an individual who was involved in the civil war in Sierra Leone from 1991 to 2002, where he was kidnapped and trained by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels. He was subjected to brutal acts, including being marked with the RUF insignia and witnessing others being tortured. After escaping, he found refuge with a preacher named Richard Cole, who inspired him to contribute positively to society.

Later, during the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone in 2014, the individual and his team, though not medical professionals, took action to combat the outbreak. They educated over 10,000 people about the virus, provided food and other necessities to affected communities, and collaborated with other agencies to establish an Ebola treatment unit. Their efforts saved numerous lives and transformed the individual's perspective on his past actions. He now advocates for investing in young people to create a better future for Sierra Leone and the world. The passage concludes with statistics on the deaths caused by the Ebola virus, including

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised funds to prevent the auction of approximately 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood firm's pension debt. The collection will remain on display at the Barlaston museum and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign's success was attributed to the spirit of goodwill and determination shown during negotiations. The collection, inherited by the Wedgwood Museum after the firm's collapse in 2009, was crucial for Staffordshire and risked being dispersed globally without the funds. The campaign's success was celebrated as it preserved the collection's cultural significance and national identity.

Dan Groves has not disclosed the finer details of a potential deal where Wright could acquire a 20% stake in the club. Wright, a former runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has a history in non-league football with clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is under new ownership by Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 weekly. The club recently signed Paul Konchesky, a former England international.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United ended with a scoreless draw. Nathan Delfouneso and Jamille Matt provided Blackpool with early opportunities, but Colchester's Sam Slocombe made crucial saves. The teams exchanged corners, with Kurtis Guthrie's shot from close range being saved by Slocombe. Blackpool's Tom Aldred had a chance from a corner but missed. Colchester's substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for violent conduct, reducing Blackpool to 10 men. The match ended with both teams scoring one goal each, and the final score was Blackpool 1, Colchester United 1.

Key events:
1. Nathan Delfouneso's chip goal for Blackpool
2. Sam Slocombe's saves for Colchester
3. Kurtis Guthrie's close-range shot for Blackpool
4. Tom Aldred's missed corner for Blackpool
5. Sean Murray's red card for Colchester
6. Both teams scoring one goal each
7. Final score: Blackpool 1, Colchester United 1.

The Fawley power station, a 1971 oil-fired 2,000 megawatt facility with a 198-meter chimney, is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as part of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The disused site, which powered one million homes, was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016. The proposed plan includes a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. With outline planning permission expected later this year, construction could begin in 2018. The developers emphasize the significance of the chimney, likening the investment required to that of the i360 in Brighton or the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth.

In the Hong Kong championships, British cyclist Latham secured the bronze medal in the men's scratch race, following behind Adrian Teklinski of Poland (gold) and Lucass Liss of Germany (silver). Meanwhile, GB's only rider in the men's keirin, Joe Truman, was eliminated in the semi-finals. In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, a member of the team, remained positive about their progress despite not medaling. Katy Marchant, a female sprinter, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint. The team's young riders, with an average age of 19, are seen as having promising futures.

EastEnders actor Ross Kemp, known for playing Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, will make a brief return to the show for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara, who left in 2010, reappears to inform her son Phil of her cancer recurrence. The producers plan to showcase emotional scenes of her death in the spring. Kemp's return reunites the Mitchell family, with Grant and Phil facing the loss of their mother. The storyline, which reunites the Mitchell brothers and showcases Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best, is considered a classic EastEnders episode.

Sadio Mane scored twice in a short span for Spurs, who struggled at Anfield, highlighting their lack of desire to win. Spurs have only won twice on the road since September and have a poor record against top-six teams away from home. Pochettino emphasized the importance of consistency and the challenge of maintaining a lead in the Premier League. Former player Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' inconsistency and suggested they should stick to their successful defensive strategy against big teams. Spurs' contrasting performance at home and away, along with a need for improvement, was also noted.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). The PDP, which had been in power for 16 years, lost control of key northern states and Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. Despite this, the PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to secure a national spread of votes. The elections were not held in seven states, and there were 66 reported violent incidents. The PDP will need to introspect and rebuild under a new leader. The APC's victory under Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, raises hopes for a maturing Nigerian democracy.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place from July 19-22 in Stornoway, offers an augmented reality app for visitors to access online information from signs and posters. The app provides videos, band interviews, and updates on the festival, enabling global interaction and capturing the festival's atmosphere. The app also allows instant access to information, ticket purchases, and a taste of the unique festival experience.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will lose their funding. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Similar warnings were issued to Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools felt undermined by parents during an Ofsted inspection. The education minister, Lord Nash, expressed concerns about the management of Park View School, including inadequate safety measures and extremist views being presented in assemblies. The Department for Education and Saltley School, under special measures, will work together to install a temporary governing board. The trusts are expected to respond to the funding termination notices by 4 July, with the Secretary of State deciding the future of the schools. Parents and staff at the schools have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 due to a build-up of fluid in his brain, which was linked to a failure by eye specialist Honey Rose to detect swollen optic discs during a routine eye test. The prosecution claims Rose's conduct was so below the expected standard that it was "criminal," as her failure to refer Vinnie for further investigation could have prevented his death. Rose denies charges of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man from Guthrie, near Forfar, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he met on an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014. He also intentionally caused the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaved threateningly on Christmas Day in 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. The woman felt blackmailed, and the judge assessed Weatherhogg as a moderate risk of re-offending. The case was remitted to the High Court due to its greater sentencing powers.

Ireland scored 165-5 against Afghanistan in a T20 match, with Stuart Thompson, Gary Wilson, and William Porterfield contributing significantly. Afghanistan, led by Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad, achieved 171-4. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early on. The Irish team acknowledged they could have scored higher but fell short with the ball. Boyd Rankin's absence due to a back problem was a setback for Ireland. The teams will face each other again on Friday. Rankin is expected to return for upcoming ODIs starting March 15.

FC Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but the total cost, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and taxes, is estimated at £106.8m. The club has made a tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to defend against potential tax-related crime accusations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season. The club's president, Sandro Rosell, is under investigation but denies wrongdoing. The case's outcome remains uncertain.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand, on September 15. Metropolitan Police officers from the UK collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the murders. The UK detectives completed their investigation and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the investigation's DNA verification and suspect treatment. The suspects face serious charges and could face the death penalty. The UK police visit was facilitated by Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Mr. Miller drowned and received a blow to the head, while Ms. Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA evidence links the suspects to Ms. Witheridge.

Scotland has won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with victory almost guaranteed a spot in the next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Iceland, ranked 20th in the world, are also unbeaten and the match outcome will determine the group leader. Scotland's player, Evans, emphasizes the importance of reaching the finals and the benefits of having players in top leagues like Germany's Bundesliga. Evans, a key player in Scotland's success, has experienced the thrill of victory in Germany's top league and values the competitive environment it provides. The Scottish team's performance is bolstered by players from various top leagues, contributing to a diverse and competitive national team.

The passage discusses the implementation of a two-step verification system by Apple to prevent third-party software from accessing celebrities' intimate photos stolen from iCloud. The new security measure requires account holders to enter a four-digit code after logging in from an unfamiliar device. If the code isn't entered, access to iCloud and related services is denied. A 14-character recovery key is also provided for account recovery in case of device loss. While the system is considered secure by its creator, concerns remain about the potential loss or theft of the recovery key. Security expert Alan Woodward suggests that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all companies. Apple plans to encourage users to enable this feature and use stronger passwords.

UKIP spent £2,956,737 on the campaign, receiving 68p per vote for their 4,376,635 votes. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote) and the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) but lost all but one of their MEPs. Labour spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote) and came second. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote) and came fourth. The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP, spent a total of £9,347,087. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals, potentially playing against his old club on February 18. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, former Port Vale manager, is joining the Gulls. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points clear of the relegation zone, despite only winning one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite no significant underlying health issues, the horse suffered from a rare "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Many Clouds, the horse in question, had previously won races and had a history of overheating, but this was the first time he collapsed. The incident has prompted further investigation into the cause of such rare haemorrhages in racehorses.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, and Duncan McNeil, a Labour MSP, both expressed emotional farewells as they stepped down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5 election. First Minister Alex Salmond, who served from 2007 to 2014, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to take on greater governance responsibilities. He criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling unionist pledges during the referendum campaign. Salmond also humorously acknowledged competition from a "major attraction down south" but assured his remarks would not overshadow the Cheltenham race. He concluded by highlighting the honor of serving Scotland and the public purpose of the parliament. McNeil, in his final speech, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also retired, humorously noting her fondness for Finance Secretary John Swinney's "huge outbursts of faux indignation."

The 2017 film features Emma Watson as Belle, with Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline plays Maurice, the father of Belle. The star of Harry Potter, Emma Watson, voices Mrs. Potts, a magically transformed teapot. The film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios and will be released in US cinemas on March 17.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will discuss its decisions regarding potential charges for 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives. The disaster resulted in 96 fatalities, with Margaret Aspinall's son among them. New inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. The meeting, led by Sue Hemming, will address the Operation Resolve investigation and an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct post-disaster. Families, including Aspinall, have expressed determination for accountability and anticipation for the outcomes.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with a former inmate claiming drones were used for smuggling. The prison's proximity to residents has led to concerns, prompting a meeting to discuss preventative measures. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and has introduced laws for potential jail time for those involved. Despite claims of drones, no evidence supports their use at the Chelmsford site.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man from Kempston. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, denied causing serious injury through dangerous driving. He admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn, who was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road when the traffic light turned red. The incident occurred outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. The case was paused for Mr. Wright to compose himself, and he expressed remorse for the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Scottish middle distance runner Muir will not participate in the next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships and set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. Despite her disappointment, she remains focused on her studies and considers the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. She believes she has the potential for future Olympic participation.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared after a Christmas party in December 2000. A search in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations, is underway and expected to last weeks. Detectives have released CCTV footage showing Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace, Bank of Ireland, and believe the man seen in the footage is the same individual captured on CCTV later on Haddington Road. The man remains unidentified, and detectives are appealing for him to come forward.

Del Potro, the 27-year-old former US Open champion, overcame injuries and returned to play in his first Grand Slam since 2014. He won against Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in the Wimbledon draw, which also includes Andy Murray and Nick Kyrgios. Del Potro's victory came after a thrilling match against Wawrinka, which he won in a tie-break. Del Potro expressed joy and a sense of being alive again, while Kyrgios also advanced, defeating Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. Feliciano Lopez and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also progressed in their respective matches. The BBC Sport app now offers tennis alerts.

Tunisia was on the verge of expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (CAF). However, after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia managed to resolve their differences. Concurrently, Morocco was able to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) reduced their fine from $1m to $50,000. The Tunisian Football Federation clarified that they never accused CAF or the Mauritian referee of corruption, but rather criticized the referee's choice and handling of the match. Tunisia and Morocco are now preparing for a future full of good things in African football.

McLaren, a team with a storied history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline in performance. Despite having two world champions in the cockpit, including arguably the best driver, Fernando Alonso, the team's recent struggles began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design and reliance on Honda power units. McLaren's past successes, such as their 1988 season sweep and the dominance of Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, have been overshadowed by recent scandals and a lack of victories. However, team boss Ron Dennis remains optimistic about a return to success, citing the team's potential to break Mercedes' dominance in F1. The team's future success is contingent on the performance of their Honda engines and the belief of their leadership.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on October 6, 2014. The bar served alcohol until 4:49 BST, violating licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge criticized the premises' management and lack of adherence to licensing laws. O'Neill received a £3,000 fine and a three-month closure order, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge expressed concern over the severity of the case and O'Neill's record.

Stephen Curry set a new NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers for the Golden State Warriors, who won against the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry's record surpassed his previous mark of 272 made in a single season. The Warriors' victory helped them avoid a three-game losing streak, while Damian Lillard scored 20 points and eight assists for the Blazers. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Derrick Rose scoring 12 points.

Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic from Liverpool were surprised when YouTube star Bas Van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, joined them at Anfield. Initially believed to be a regular fan, Van Velzen showcased his abilities, impressing the players. The experience was enjoyable for Van Velzen, who got to interact with Liverpool's stars and even unveiled Balotelli's famous slogan.

omen diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed. A study found that this procedure, known as oophorectomy, cuts the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%. The research, conducted in Canada, involved 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes. The study revealed a 77.4% 20-year survival rate for the group, with a 62% decrease in breast cancer death for BRCA1 mutation carriers post-oophorectomy. However, this benefit was not observed in BRCA2 mutation carriers. The study also noted a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The findings suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were killed in a train accident in Durham, North Carolina, on Easter Sunday. The Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, was en route from Charlotte to New York City when it struck the couple on the tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern. The accident caused a two-hour and 45-minute delay, during which 166 passengers were onboard, but none were injured. A man fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The couple may have been homeless, as they were seen with a grocery cart. The train continued its journey to Raleigh after the incident.

arlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years. He fled Colombia in the 1980s due to a confrontation with his boss. Toro provided crucial information that led to the prosecution of drug lords like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, the DEA refused to assist him with citizenship, leaving him in the US illegally. Toro fears deportation, as he believes it would be fatal if sent back to Colombia. He is currently unable to obtain a green card or passport, and his temporary visa expired in January. Toro's former colleague provided him with $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined to help. He remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits until he secures a legal status.

The US regulator is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd.'s use of the '.sucks' domain name, which has been exploited by the company to charge celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major brands exorbitant fees to remove their names. The domain, initially approved by ICANN, has faced criticism from industry groups and companies, with concerns about its legality and potential consumer impact. Kevin Spacey has reportedly paid to have his name removed from the '.sucks' domain, and ICANN may take action if the company's practices are found to be illegal. The '.sucks' domain is priced at around $2,499 per year, with resellers selling them for approximately $2,000 annually.

A mother of a stillborn baby boy, discovered in a pond in Norfolk in 1988, was arrested 27 years later after DNA led police to her. The woman, who concealed her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone and placed it in the pond before it was found by teenagers. After the body was exhumed and a second post-mortem found no foul play, the woman was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped. The baby, now named Peter, was reburied at St. Peter's Church. The case, which remained unsolved for 27 years, was finally closed using modern DNA techniques. The support group Hana's Gift paid for a new headstone for Peter, and the coroner's chaplain expressed hope that the mother might seek support if she comes forward.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving car. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was trying to escape and drove him back to the taxi rank, causing Hicks to jump from the vehicle at over 20mph. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care and has developed epilepsy. The judge ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, and the compensation amount, around 50% of the family's requested sum, will be decided in a further hearing. Hicks' family is represented by lawyer James Davies, who highlighted the long-term impact of the incident on Hicks' life.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as several storms reported twisters, with one sighted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard. The storm moved northeast, avoiding Wichita but posing risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most deadly and dangerous. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri's Potosi also experienced a possible tornado, with reports of wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

uke Rockhold is preparing to compete against Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey. Rockhold aims for his fourth consecutive victory, targeting a title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by being the aggressive force, contrasting Machida's style. Rockhold has identified Machida's weaknesses and is confident in his own skills, including takedowns, kicks, and punches. Machida, on the other hand, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and secure a title shot. Both fighters are well-prepared, with Rockhold having eight weeks of camp and Machida having trained with various fighters. The outcome of the fight could determine who deserves a title shot.

An aeroplane made an unintended belly landing at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, due to the pilot forgetting to deploy the landing gear. The aircraft skidded along the runway, causing damage to the propellers and creating a memorable sound. Despite the incident, the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, managed to safely take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale with his dog, Buddy. The FAA is investigating the cause, which is typically human error or mechanical fault.

anuel Pellegrini, manager of Manchester City, has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance but has pledged to support him until the season ends. Despite criticism amid the team's poor Premier League defense, Pellegrini emphasizes Toure's importance and loyalty. City is open to offers for Toure in the summer, as they plan to overhaul their aging squad. Meanwhile, Manchester City's goalkeeper Joe Hart urges players to take responsibility for their underperformance. Sam Allardyce warns Aaron Cresswell not to repeat the mistakes of other English players by moving to City. Allardyce sees Cresswell as a valuable prospect for clubs to fill homegrown player quotas.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy for a seven-year sentence handed down in 1999 for his membership in the Cosa Nostra. However, his case expired in October of the previous year, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Rancadore, who has lived in the UK for over 20 years, will now be allowed to remain in the UK. The Italian authorities' failure to appeal against the district judge's decision in March 2014, which denied Rancadore's extradition, played a key role in this outcome. The Italian Ministry of Justice confirmed that the decision by the court of appeal in Palermo is appealable to the Italian Supreme Court. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) admitted a mistake in failing to serve appeal papers on time, which could have potentially prevented Rancadore's extradition. Rancadore's lawyers filed an application for his sentence to be declared expired, which was confirmed by the court in

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He will compete alongside Irish Raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. Mr. Mole will be A.P. McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, with his book of rides for the final day as a professional jockey to be finalized on Friday morning. McCoy's decision to quit riding came after a victory with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Somersby by Mick Channon.

Marcia Trimble Ritter, the daughter of Virginia Trimble Ritter, was raped and strangled to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was discovered 33 days after her disappearance in a garage. Despite her then-husband's advice against viewing the crime scene photos, Ritter eventually asked to see them and expressed a desire for revenge. The photos showed the extent of the violence, with Barrett's DNA matching that found on Marcia's clothing. Barrett was later convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison. Ritter's request to see the photos was a decision she regretted, as the images were disturbing and did not resemble the Marcia she remembered.

ory McIlroy, the world number one, aspires to complete the career grand slam by winning the Masters at Augusta National. Despite a significant collapse in 2011, McIlroy views this as a pivotal moment in his career. He has previously won the US Open, US PGA, and both the Open and US PGA in the past year. McIlroy aims to emulate legends like Jack Nicklaus by securing all four major titles. He believes Augusta National is a course he can excel at and potentially win multiple times. McIlroy's success in 2012 was achieved amidst personal distractions, and he considers the golf course as his sanctuary from the pressures of Augusta. He is determined to focus on playing his best golf during the tournament.

The passage highlights several trending stories from a busy week. In New York, rainbows appeared after heavy rain, captured by fashion company CEO Amanda Curtis. In rural China, hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common, but faces government crackdown. RDJ expressed agitation during a UK interviewer's questions. Lip plumping trend emerged with a hashtag for Kylie Jenner's look. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, was filmed time-traveling with filmmakers. A prom-posal involving bombs sparked accusations of racism. Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer gained social media attention. Pregnancy announcements referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." A military dad photobombed his son, earning praise for originality.

Over the past year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to foetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by prenatal exposure to alcohol. Experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be higher, with research suggesting that up to one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to maternal alcohol consumption. The condition is often under-diagnosed and can result in lifelong disabilities, as seen in the case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires assistance with daily tasks and will never be able to live independently. Associated medical issues include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government currently advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to up to two units twice a week, but some advocate for a complete abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," was arrested and jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. Mckerry, an ex-juvenile offender with a history of repeated crimes, including shoplifting and burglary, was stopped by store owner Sab Dhillon and his wife Sam. Dhillon tackled Mckerry, causing him to drop the axe, while Sam struck him with a baseball bat twice, aiding in his disarmament. Mckerry was arrested by the police minutes later. His criminal activities earned him the nicknames due to his pattern of returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors from the UK, Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, are charged with gang rape of a young woman at a party in Nova Scotia, Canada. They were given bail conditions that could see them living on a Canadian naval base for several years, surrendering their passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy. The alleged assault took place on April 10, after a hockey game. The investigation is ongoing, and the sailors are forbidden from contacting the victim and witnesses. They must remain employed by the navy and cannot apply for new passports. The case is serious, with potential sentences of up to 14 years in prison. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation.

mother, Valerie Jackson, was mistakenly accused of child abuse due to her son RJ's rare skin condition, Netherton's Syndrome. RJ, one of only 70 people worldwide with this condition, has red, scaly skin that resembles scalding. Valerie and her husband, Reginald, have to apply creams to RJ's skin multiple times a day to alleviate his painful symptoms. Despite their efforts, they face ignorance and taunts from strangers, including being surrounded by armed police while shopping. RJ's condition, a severe form of ichthyosis, causes his skin to lose heat, water, and protein, making him susceptible to infections. There is no cure, but symptoms often improve with age. Valerie found support and information through a Facebook group for parents of children with Netherton's Syndrome.

he controversial Protein World advertisement featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield, has sparked outrage among feminists and body image campaigners. The ads, displayed on the London Underground, have been defaced by bloggers and received over 200 complaints from the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA). Despite the backlash, Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the removal of the posters as they had reached the end of the three-week advertising period paid for by Protein World. The company has also expressed its intention to consider public reaction in future advertising decisions. The debate has gained momentum with a protest in Hyde Park and significant social media activity, including threats against the company. Protein World's marketing head defended the campaign, stating it aimed to inspire health and fitness, while critics argue it promotes unrealistic body standards. The company's sales have been growing, with protein powder becoming increasingly popular in the UK.

Prime Minister David Cameron has urged First Great Western to review its decision to almost double fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which affects his Witney constituents. Despite political parties pledging to freeze fares, the company plans to increase fares by up to 87% for off-peak returns from Charlbury to London. The planned changes have sparked anger among constituents, leading to the Prime Minister's intervention. Train companies have three annual windows to increase unregulated fares, which make up about half of their total revenue. First Great Western insists the fare increase is to align the Cotswolds route with other services, while offering cheaper options for some customers. Other significant fare hikes are planned for various routes, with Virgin Trains stating that the majority of its price increases affect "virgin trains-only fares," which are cheaper than competitors.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his Oldham home. The attack occurred three weeks after John married his partner Elaine, 54, and they were writing thank you cards for wedding gifts when the incident happened. John was hit when he opened the front door to confront the attackers, resulting in an open wound to his forehead and serious injury to his left eye. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The police launched an investigation but found no motive, suggesting it could be a case of youths "messing around." John and Elaine, now fearing for their safety, plan to move to a different neighborhood.

erbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, who missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident where his father died, has signed a new one-year contract extension. The former England under-19 international underwent an ankle operation but made a successful comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing delight at his return and hoping the new contract will boost his confidence for the upcoming season.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, battled an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer, for a year. Diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, Harley used a ninja turtle mask during his radiotherapy to feel stronger. His story gained international attention, leading to a box of ninja turtle presents from Nickelodeon. After undergoing intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy, Harley was declared cancer-free. He will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure he remains free of the disease. Harley's bravery and his family's journey have made him the face of the charity's campaign to raise funds for child cancer research.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old footballer, has impressed with Aston Villa in their recent semi-final win over Liverpool. Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, advises Grealish to focus on securing his place in the Villa first team before considering his international future with either the Republic of Ireland or England. Sherwood emphasizes that the decision is ultimately up to Grealish, who must continue to perform well for Villa. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees with Sherwood's advice, stating that Grealish's club commitments should come first. Grealish is currently torn between the two countries and will need to make a decision at the end of the season.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jets, which is a luxury afforded only by the wealthy. These fees vary significantly, with some of the most expensive being in Japan, particularly Haneda Airport in Tokyo. The fees are influenced by factors such as the popularity of the airport during major sporting events. The top 10 most expensive airports for landing fees include Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Toronto Pearson International Airport in Toronto, Darwin International Airport in Darwin, Bristol Airport in Bristol, Chūbu Centrair International Airport in Nagoya, Dublin Airport in Dublin, and Salzburg Airport in Salzburg. The fees are based on the 767-400 aircraft model and can reach thousands of dollars per landing. The industry is valued at $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013. The most popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, takes her Labrador, Cooper, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream with his friend, Daisy. Cooper quickly devours the ice cream cone, while Daisy takes only a few licks due to her smaller size. Despite criticism from some viewers, Gallegos defends her actions, citing Cooper's athleticism and good health. The video has garnered over seven million views. Gallegos also mentions a Starbucks visit where Cooper consumes a "pup-uccino" cup in one go.

Gary Locke, former Kilmarnock assistant manager, has been appointed as the permanent manager after a successful interim period. He joined the club last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston and took over when Johnston quit in February. Since then, Locke has led the team to a record of seven wins in seven games. He will sign a three-year deal and will address the press on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, is disputing a school's threat to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing essential oils that smell and distract other children. The oils, produced by Doterra, are applied to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Despite a teacher's aide complaint, Kemp insists the oils have a positive impact on her son. The school initially stated the oils created a problem for staff and students, but later clarified it was a health issue. The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. Doterra has not yet commented on the situation.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, Hamptons, was destroyed by a fierce fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings, spread through 90 condos before the structure collapsed. The cause of the fire remains unknown, with investigations suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex. Twelve fire crews struggled to control the flames, but were unable to enter the summer homes. The complex, which is used as a holiday home between May and November, saw residents and the building manager, Rob Taber, lose everything. Witnesses reported seeing the flames from three miles away. The fire chief mentioned that the wind was offshore, providing good visibility for firefighting efforts.

The Queen, at 88, enjoys riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite being encouraged to wear helmets for safety, she prefers silk scarves due to her hair. The Queen has a long-standing love for horses, starting with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four. She has ridden various horses throughout her life, including Betsey and Surprise, and has even galloped at Ascot in 1961. Recently, she has reduced her riding time due to a knee injury but remains an enthusiastic equestrienne. The Queen also breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court, including highland ponies at Balmoral. Fell ponies, with their history dating back to the Neolithic period, have been used for packing, transportation, and racing, and are now popular for family riding. The Queen's breeding of fell ponies at Hampton Court highlights her enduring passion for these ancient, hardy animals.

Two Brisbane neighbors, Leon Yeaman (55) and Phillip Pama (28), had a fatal argument over noise levels. Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from Pama during a confrontation in front of their homes. Pama, a shift worker and father of three, was granted conditional bail and faced restrictions such as a curfew and reporting to the police station. Yeaman was known for his loud music and drinking habits, while Pama claimed he was pushed and did not see the punch connect. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, planned to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. The plan was uncovered by police who set up a sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman. Simonova demanded the boy suffer unbearable pain, specifically targeting his kidneys and limbs. After handing over expense money, she was arrested in her car and charged with attempted murder. Simonova had previously showered Vanya with gifts during their affair. Vanya, who ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief and hope for Simonova's imprisonment.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea football manager, has revealed that he prays to God daily but does not discuss football with him or his wife, Matilde. Despite his competitive and emotional professional life, Mourinho maintains a strong personal faith, praying only for personal matters. He attends church regularly in Portugal but not frequently in England. Mourinho is a family man and friend, supporting people beyond his immediate circle. He acknowledges making mistakes in his professional life but believes that a person's life extends beyond their career. Mourinho and his family were present at the Hunger Games premiere.

Bob Barker, a TV game show legend, returned to host "The Price Is Right" after an eight-year absence. At 91, he managed the first game, "Lucky Seven," before passing the hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite his absence, Barker appeared spry and seamlessly transitioned back into his role.

An off-duty secret service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. Baldwin, who works with the foreign missions branch of the service, had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave. His arrest occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin was arraigned on Friday afternoon, but no attorney was listed in court records and a phone number could not be found. This incident follows another case involving a high-ranking supervisor accused of misconduct, which is also under police investigation. Both cases have negatively impacted the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family. The inspector general is investigating these allegations.

tif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from a few feet away in a city safari park. Saeed crept up to the lion, armed only with a camera, and managed to take a few frames before retreating to his car. However, the sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to flee rapidly. Reflecting on the incident, Saeed admits he wouldn't repeat the close encounter.

The New York City Police have released images of a distinctive heart tattoo with the name "Monique" on an unidentified woman's right leg in hopes of identifying her. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 in Brooklyn. Paramedics were unable to revive her, and she was pronounced dead that evening. The tattoo features the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and are encouraging anyone with information to contact Nypd Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a self-sufficient, solar-powered two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 due to financial constraints. The project, which took about a year and a half, involved constructing a steel frame and adding wood and stained glass windows. The home, costing around $25,000, features a wood-fired stove, gas-powered hot water, and water from a nearby spring. The couple now enjoys living in a cozy, nature-surrounded home, with plans to build another similar structure in the future.

Researchers found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers in early literacy tests. The study, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, involved 352 students and suggested that collaborative learning around technology, rather than just the technology itself, was the key factor in the improved outcomes. The findings have led to suggestions that schools should reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without hind legs in Sichuan Province, China, has gained internet fame for learning to walk on its front trotters. The heartwarming video shows the piglet, nicknamed "super pig," wobbling and foraging for food alongside its fully-legged siblings. Villagers and tourists are drawn to witness the extraordinary balance and determination of the two-legged piglet, which has become a sensation online. The piglet, owned by farmer Ms. Duan, has also inspired its siblings to mimic its unique gait. This is not the first instance of an animal with two legs in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo has also attracted attention for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car struck him on lap 25. Dracone, who spun out exiting his pit box, did not finish the race and ended up in 23rd place. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut and was subsequently released from the infield care center. The race faced traction issues due to rain-soaked conditions.

A husband, Milton Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, after accusing her of being a slut. The horrific act was captured on CCTV, showing Severiano smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy of men looking at his wife as the motive. The couple had only been married for four days. The crime scene was discovered with four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in Severiano's car. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," disclosed her personal struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and thyroid disease, which led her to consider suicide. She felt isolated and struggled to find meaning in life. Wilson believes depression and anxiety are linked, and acknowledging this connection is crucial to address the growing impact of stress and anxiety on Australian women. She now accepts her anxiety and encourages seeking help through organizations like beyondblue and lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The incident occurred when Curtin discovered the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, citing Curtin's justification for her actions. The ex-girlfriend had been harassing Curtin and attempting to involve her boyfriend in addiction. Curtin gave birth in January and has since reconciled with her boyfriend, living with her parents. If convicted, Curtin would have faced almost six years in prison.

Gemma the pit bull, filmed in California, was tricked by her owner into eating a broccoli spear. The dog reacted with disgust, spitting the vegetable out. The passage suggests that the young children living with Gemma may learn to dislike greens if they follow her example. However, Gemma also enjoys spending time with her family and sleeping.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic page. The link was originally for the young entrepreneur awards, which was shut down in 2011. The porn site had taken over the address after the awards were scrapped and the organizers allowed its registration on HSBC's website. HSBC removed the hyperlink and denied any association with the external site, offering an apology to the public. The banking giant insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, provided crucial instructions to firefighters during a 911 call when a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton. Marcus and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped on the second floor due to intense heat. Marcus remained calm, guiding the firefighters to the room and instructing Aaliyah to stay low and breathe. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room through a broken window and rescued Marcus and Aaliyah. Marcus was also given a gas mask by firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward. The siblings sustained non-life-threatening injuries and were taken to a children's hospital, while the rest of the family escaped on their own. Marcus's bravery was praised by firefighter Assistant Chief Alan Doubleday.

In Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay on the South Coast of New South Wales, breathtaking images have surfaced showcasing blue fluorescent algae illuminating popular beaches. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the phenomenon as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. This display, similar to one observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, is attributed to the presence of noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn. Iain Suther, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explains that this carnivorous cell, which preys on diatoms, emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism. The occurrence is natural and happens in 90% of cases.

ew tests, such as endopredict, can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness and risk of recurrence after surgery. These tests, which cost around £2,500 privately, can provide results within days and indicate whether a woman has a high or low risk of cancer returning. For some women, the test can show a low risk as low as five per cent, which is comparable to or better than the odds of those who undergo chemotherapy. This information can help patients make informed decisions about their treatment options, potentially sparing them from the grueling and side-effect-laden chemotherapy. The National Health Service (NHS) may soon make these tests more widely available, as they could save costs by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. A case study of a woman, Becca Cornford, illustrates the benefits of this approach, as she opted not to undergo chemotherapy after receiving a low-risk score from the endopredict test.

ver 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including one from HMS Illustrious. The evacuations occurred on various ships, with 18 emergencies reported. The strict "no touching" rule at sea suggests pregnancies likely occurred before boarding or during leave. The true number of evacuations may be higher as routine flights were also used. Pregnant servicewomen are banned from war zones, and the ministry of defense does not confirm reasons for evacuations or potential consequences for those involved.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, specifically cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House. This alarming discovery comes amidst Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's controversial plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, has raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga emphasized the need for continuous examination of drone operations and counter-terrorism measures. The government plans to prevent such threats, despite current laws restricting drone flights around airports in Tokyo. Prime Minister Abe was not present at the time of the discovery, as he was attending an international conference.

security guard from Zhejiang Province in China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work on the back of his motorbike every day due to her Alzheimer's disease and fear of her getting lost. He ensures her safety by tying a sash around their waists and riding slowly. His mother, who once carried him as a child, now relies on him for care. Lu's employer, a bank, provides her with a room to prevent her from wandering off. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother in return for her lifelong dedication to her children.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington reveals a 17.2% increase in heavy drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise in binge drinking rates, especially among women. This trend is attributed to changing social norms and economic factors, such as increased affluence and cheaper alcohol prices. The study, which tracked drinking patterns at the county level, also noted that despite the rise in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who consume alcohol has remained relatively stable. The research highlights the need for stronger alcohol control policies and increased access to treatment for alcohol addiction.

Doctors are warned to avoid unnecessary caesarean sections, as they pose risks to women and babies, potentially leading to infections, disability, or death. The World Health Organization (WHO) suggests the ideal caesarean rate should be between 10% and 15%, but the current rate in England is over 25%, having more than doubled since the early 1990s. The NHS reports that a planned caesarean costs £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO statement contradicts NHS guidelines, which previously allowed caesareans without medical justification, especially for women with tokophobia or previous complicated births. The WHO criticizes the overuse of caesareans, which diverts funds from other patients.

Michelle Filkins, a 44-year-old woman from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for breaking into a $800,000 summer home on Martha's Vineyard. She allegedly lived inside for a week, during which she sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. Charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, Filkins was found by owner Mark Conklin sitting in the living room. When Conklin called the police, Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck. Police discovered a broken window and various missing items, including furniture, kitchenware, and a painting. The Edgartown Police Department is seeking restitution for those who received items from the home and has provided contact information for those who may have purchased something.

Bella Crooke's lost iPhone was found and returned to her by Albury police after being handed in at the police station. The officers, recognizing Bella from her Facebook page, posted selfies and puns on her page to track her down. The posts included humorous messages about the phone being in a "cell" and its battery being "fully charged." Bella was able to reclaim her phone without revealing her name. The police's unconventional approach was praised by Bella's friends, who shared the posts and called the officers "legends." Bella has since added a password to her phone. The phone was later confirmed to have not been claimed by the police.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed during a fight between two adult hippos in the isimangaliso wetland park, eastern South Africa. The calf was flung into the air and dragged along the water surface, witnessed by its mother and tour operator Stacey Farrell. The mother, attempting to protect her calf, was unable to prevent the sub-adult hippo from grabbing and ultimately killing the baby. The exact motive behind the attack remains unknown. The calf died hours after the incident.

three-bedroom apartment in one of Britain's most expensive areas, Knightsbridge, is on sale for £575,000, significantly lower than neighboring homes. However, the property has a three-year lease remaining. The cost per year or month is comparable to renting a similar-sized flat in the area. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth over £6 million. The maisonette, described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space, requires modernization. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The property, built in 1893, has a history of high-status residents. Potential buyers are advised to consider the premium for lease extension.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting sales registers at 8,000 US and 1,000 Canadian stores, prompting baristas to give away free drinks. The outage, which began on the east coast in the early evening and on the west coast in the late afternoon, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. Despite the inconvenience, Starbucks remained open and continued to serve customers, with some locations choosing to close early to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings.

Terrorists are being trained in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. These locations are also being used to radicalize Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasizes that terrorism is not confined to large cities and that community intelligence plays a crucial role in identifying potential threats. The area's rugged terrain is used by the British military for training, and there have been instances of individuals connected to terrorist activities, such as studying Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences. The community's vigilance is essential in combating these threats.

An Omura's whale, previously feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting in the region and only the second in Australia. The discovery, made after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, allowed scientists to confirm the species through DNA profiling. The whale, a juvenile female, has unique features such as 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass will be buried and its skeleton will be studied in the future. The Omura's whale is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. This find is significant for whale scientists as it will aid in improving field identification guides and understanding the species' regional distribution.

The passage discusses the controversial viewpoint of a female businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, who believes that a woman's hormones could make her an irrational president, potentially leading to unnecessary wars. Rios argues against a woman being president, despite acknowledging equal rights. The passage also highlights studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. It criticizes Rios's views and emphasizes the need to address gender bias in the workplace to ensure equal opportunities for women. The passage concludes by stating that equality benefits everyone, including the economy, children, marriages, and corporate teams. It also mentions Canada's first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, as an example of successful female leadership.

Robert Hardy, an 89-year-old veteran actor, is auctioning off his extensive collection of over 200 antiques, including a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, and a portrait of him holding a longbow. Hardy, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, has amassed his collection through his interest in classic literature and military history. The auction, organized by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, will take place in Gloucestershire. Hardy, who has appeared in numerous television dramas and films, including as Winston Churchill, is sad to part with his collection but hopes those who acquire his items will find joy and pleasure in them as he has.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son. The body was found at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida. Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness, was on parole for battery on law enforcement, and was involuntarily committed for attempted suicide. His mother may have prevented him from meeting his son due to ongoing divorce proceedings. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself, and authorities are urging anyone with information to contact them. The murder weapon has been found, but authorities have not confirmed the cause of death.

Eugene, United States, has been granted the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, a decision made by the IAAF Council due to a unique strategic opportunity. This move bypasses the usual bidding process, which Eugene previously failed in for the 2019 event, awarded to Doha instead. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, highlighted the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the National Olympic Committee, NBC, and the enthusiastic public as a key factor in this decision. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

eonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was found guilty of manslaughter for luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a bid to steal his winnings. Granger used her looks to befriend Hassan, who was known for his gambling habits and large cash winnings. After spending time together, Granger left Hassan unlocked at his flat, allowing her boyfriend and accomplice, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, to enter and brutally kill him. Granger was sentenced to 16 years in jail, while Jackson and Chandler received life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by Judge William Kennedy. Granger's co-defendants were also found guilty of murder and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. The case highlighted the vulnerability of Hassan, who enjoyed the company of women and kept his winnings at home, making him an easy target for the deceitful scheme.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the latter part of the season, with his performance declining since a successful start. Despite his happiness playing every minute for Chelsea, his form has dipped, raising concerns about his durability. Fabregas's performance in his first international appearance since October was poor, with just four out of ten by a Spanish newspaper. Although he has contributed to Chelsea's Premier League title chances with a capital one cup win, his role as a key player has diminished. Fabregas's former club, Barcelona, noted his tendency to experience a late-season slump. With nine games left, Chelsea still faces opponents that Fabregas has previously opened up for goals. Fabregas's form could significantly impact Chelsea's title race, and Jose Mourinho hopes for a late-season resurgence.

West Ham is negotiating a deal with Jamaican player Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial at the club's academy. Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs. West Ham aims to fill the Olympic Stadium with affordable season tickets priced as low as £289, marking the cheapest pricing strategy in the Premier League.

iltshire police have halted an investigation into a vicious assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite evidence pointing to the attackers. The incident occurred on January 24, where Lane was beaten by protesters wearing balaclavas and armed with iron bars on ropes. Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The police have not identified the suspects, citing insufficient evidence. Lane and other hunt supporters are frustrated by the police's decision, which they believe is due to the difficulty of identifying attackers in rural areas. The countryside alliance is advocating for a ban on face coverings to aid in criminal identification. The police have stated that the case will be re-opened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a prominent member of Al Qaeda, speaking against the United States on behalf of the terrorist organization. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He became Al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist and was involved in numerous videos threatening attacks on U.S. cities and criticizing American presidents. Gadahn was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006 and was among the FBI's most wanted terrorists. He was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January, along with warren weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto, a hostage abducted by Al Qaeda in Pakistan in 2011. Gadahn was married to a Muslim woman from Afghanistan and had at least one child.

ive-year-old Chinese child Mai Zizhuo has showcased exceptional basketball skills in a viral video, dribbling two basketballs and scoring hoops, impressing fans across basketball-loving China. Despite his young age, his talent has sparked admiration and astonishment, with netizens leaving thousands of comments. Some express disbelief, while others feel inadequate in comparison, with one even wishing to reincarnate to start anew. Mai's skills have also drawn comparisons to NBA star Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) that campaigned for child sex legalization in the 70s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group "Hacked Off." O'Carroll, previously a key member of PIE and a former open university information officer, attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament to advocate for state involvement in media regulation. The group, formed post-phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation and seeks MPs to establish a statutory body for press regulation. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is seen as an embarrassment due to his past with PIE. The National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which O'Carroll was part of, had lobbied for lowering the age of sexual consent to ten with understanding and apparent consent. O'Carroll was also involved in the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was imprisoned in 1981 for corrupting public morals. The Hack

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained for Mercedes-Benz fashion week Australia, transforming it into a unique catwalk for a monochrome ten-piece unisex clothing collection. The show, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, featured models parading through the empty pool and break wall, with ocean views as a backdrop. The collection, designed for versatility in 20 different ways, was presented on a warm day with guests enjoying nibbles and drinks. The event attracted public attention, with beachgoers and passers-by stopping to watch the show.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamya. They enjoyed feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Khan later announced his next fight would be against Chris Algieri on May 30, moving away from speculation of fighting Kell Brooks or other fighters.

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims after objections from his family and the organization Almagor. Abu Khdeir was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His father and Almagor, which opposes his inclusion on the memorial, argued that his death was a rogue attack and not a terror incident. Following his father's complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name from the wall. The teenager's name was already removed from the organization's website. A panel of judges began hearing evidence against the suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing in January.

Lionel Hutz, a California-based YouTuber, captured footage of his young son attempting to rest by using their family cat as a makeshift pillow. The video shows the cat licking its fur before the boy places himself on top. The cat quickly moves to another spot, and the boy follows. This sequence repeats, but eventually, the cat leaves for indoors. Later, the boy and cat reconcile, with the boy feeding the cat treats. The cat's initial amusement quickly turns to annoyance as it seeks a more comfortable resting place.

Robert Kushner, a former varsity basketball coach at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, lost his job after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, a former drug dealer, testified that undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him in 2007. Despite the charges being expunged as part of his probationary sentence, Kushner was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Kushner maintains his innocence regarding the 2011 charges and continues to coach in a summer league. The police corruption trial involving Kushner and other former drug squad officers is ongoing.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province injured five people and caused a fire. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak. Over 600 firefighters extinguished the fire, which is now under control. The incident reignited concerns about the plant's location, which was moved from Xiamen to a more remote area in 2007 due to pollution issues. The plant has previously experienced an explosion in 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. Demonstrations against PX plants have occurred in several Chinese cities.

ack Grealish, a teenage player for Aston Villa, is known for wearing his socks low during matches due to a superstition. Despite referees' attempts to change his practice, Grealish insists on continuing with his tradition. He made his first Premier League start for Villa against QPR, expressing satisfaction despite the game's outcome. Grealish hopes to secure more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, suffers from global and irreversible brain damage. Despite being out of a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and has not shown improvement in her condition. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed her sorrow and trust in God for a miracle. Brown's condition has been stable for nearly three months, and she has a tracheostomy. Bobby Brown stated that his daughter is awake and undergoing a long rehabilitation process, with the future quality of her life still uncertain.

Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova of Russia defeated Sabine Lisicki of Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie, with Svetlana Kuznetsova also winning against Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with rhythm due to Lisicki's powerful play, and both players had serve issues, with Lisicki's 63 unforced errors being crucial. Russia needs one more win to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are warned to prepare for more floods and damage due to an incoming storm, similar to the one that caused significant damage last week. The storm, an east coast low, is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, particularly affecting the northern rivers and mid north coasts.
