Over 392,000 COVID-19 cases have been reported globally, with more than 17,100 fatalities and over 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's call-up to the England squad, expressing his belief that Townsend shouldn't have been in the squad after being pulled off at Manchester United. However, Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, leading Merson to admit his mistake and express genuine pleasure for Townsend's achievement. Despite their previous disagreement, the tension between Merson and Townsend seemed to have subsided.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's forward Yoshinori Muto, who is currently on loan at Vitesse Arnhem. Muto, a 22-year-old Japan international with 11 caps and 16 goals for FC Tokyo, has also scored 13 times in his debut season. Despite the offer, Muto has not yet decided to join Chelsea. The offer is not related to the £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree and has been named in the J-League's best XI. He has also scored three goals in four games for FC Tokyo this season. The deal for Muto is estimated at £4 million.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight toddlers. Finnish researchers analyzed the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese. Children who had received antibiotics as infants, especially boys, had a higher likelihood of being overweight. The study suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by altering gut bacteria, potentially increasing food intake and appetite. The researchers emphasize the need for judicious use of antibiotics in infancy, considering their potential role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic. Previous studies have also linked antibiotic use in babies to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems. The overuse of antibiotics is a growing concern, as it may lead to reduced effectiveness and increased difficulty in treating common infections.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing and slid sideways, knocking his bearskin and dropping his rifle. The guard's embarrassment was evident as he quickly regained his composure, with the incident occurring in front of numerous tourists. The guard's fall is believed to be due to metal protectors on his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E, Lifetime, and History are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which had over 100 million viewers. The new version, co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, will be more contemporary and draw from Alex Haley's novel. Scholars in African and African-American history will be consulted for authenticity. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, amidst current racial issues. Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, emphasizes the importance of the story for young Americans. The new adaptation will air in 2016.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that Clarence House aides attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, was accosted by two men after entering a bedroom on his first day of work. He was groped by a senior staff member and another man performed a sex act on himself, prompting a third man to grab Lawler and hold him in a chair. Lawler left his job immediately and later filed a complaint, which was initially ignored but eventually passed to Scotland Yard. The Royal Household has pledged cooperation with the police investigation. A retired royal aide denied involvement, stating he was working for the Queen in Balmoral during the incident. Lawler, now 64, has been haunted by the incident for years.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, a couple from Oregon, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The couple humorously addressed the inquiries from family and friends about their readiness for a child, and shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end. The video was created to inform distant loved ones about the baby, and the couple expressed surprise at its popularity. The Meeks are also related to Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

Vivien Leigh's dress from the 1939 film Gone With the Wind, featuring a black zigzag applique, sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, had faded to light gray with age. It was part of James Tumblin's collection of over 300,000 film memorabilia, which he began collecting in the 1960s. Tumblin purchased the dress for $20 after discovering it was about to be discarded. The auction also included other top items, such as a straw hat worn by Leigh, Rhett Butler's suit, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 book, celebrated its 75th anniversary and marked the first time an African-American actor, Hattie McDaniel, won an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled by his parents over a 10-12ft drop. The child, who suffered minor injuries, was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. The incident led to the zoo planning to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents, possibly due to fear. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera, previously enforcing a 30mph limit in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been non-functional for over two years due to all fixed devices being turned off in the West Midlands. Around 300 old-technology cameras were decommissioned in 2013. The re-pointed camera in Wellington Road is under investigation, with no plans to include it in a new digital technology pilot. The owners of the house targeted by the camera were unreachable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt is fit and healthy, and he aims to uphold Jamaica's successful relay tradition. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) is pleased with his selection, expecting Bolt to deliver impressive performances. The full Jamaican team list for the event will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending a Euro League basketball match. Neymar, the Brazilian captain, led his national team to a 1-0 victory over Chile. Barcelona won their El Clasico match against Real Madrid, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga. Neymar and Alves returned to La Liga to play against Celta Vigo, continuing their pursuit of a treble of trophies. Rafaella, Neymar's sister, also attended the basketball match.

Italy is experiencing a surge in desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received SOS calls from 20 boats in distress. Save the Children fears 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the coast guard has not found evidence of such an incident. The International Organization for Migration reports over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first quarter of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the beginning of the year, at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason. Sanchez, after being courted by elite clubs, joined Arsenal and has made an instant impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez as a potential leverage point during negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer but believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to the English environment proves his quality. Wenger also downplays speculation about a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, praising Brendan Rodgers' team development following Suarez's sale and Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, aims to surpass the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis. Wiggins' attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports and tickets will go on sale from April 19. Wiggins is also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams, a French Open champion, struggled to defeat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, resulting in a 3-2 loss for the US. Williams' performance was affected by the tough weather conditions, and she admitted she was not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought. Despite her defeat in doubles, Williams won her singles match, but the loss highlighted the need for the US to improve and work harder to return to the elite nations. The US has several top 100 players who could potentially help achieve this goal.

River Plate, an Argentine football club, is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, a former Manchester United striker. Falcao, who has struggled with a loan spell at Old Trafford, has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games. He joined River Plate in 2001 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for the club during his four seasons. Vice president Matias Patanian confirms the club's interest and openness to Falcao's return. The decision on whether Falcao will return to River Plate or stay with Manchester United is pending.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The campaign, which showcases a variety of hairstyles, features Henderson with her long, flowing locks styled in a half-ponytail. The partnership was established by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, "Mirror Man." Henderson, who uses Batiste regularly, expressed excitement about the collaboration. The campaign is seen as the first endorsement for Henderson, who is managed by Crown Talent & Media Group.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after Siler allegedly armed himself during a confrontation. The shooting occurred on March 14, and Torres is on leave pending an investigation. A billboard featuring Torres and his dog, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends, who find it disrespectful and demand its removal. The police association defends the billboard as a gesture of gratitude for community support amid recent incidents. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while Torres' shooting of Terry Knight, a 66-year-old man with two knives, was deemed justified by District Attorney Robert Zapf.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces in Negur, Sistan-Baluchestan province. The militant group Jaish al Adal, which aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials have called for Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving militants. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and pledged to investigate and apprehend any militants who entered Pakistan.

The Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). In response to a question from Antonio Inoki, Nakatani stated that while they sometimes find birds or other flying objects, they have not found any UFOs believed to originate from outer space. Inoki, a former wrestler and politician, has previously claimed to have seen a UFO but admitted uncertainty about the existence of aliens. The discussion on extraterrestrial threats has occurred before, with former Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considering the legal implications under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, Anhui Province, China, collapsed and shattered. Jin Pai initially claimed he was sitting on the toilet but later admitted to squatting. He was too embarrassed to call for help, leading to severe injuries requiring stitches. Authorities believe the incident was accidental and urged people to use the toilets for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested on multiple charges after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. The girl reported that Rebbie had been sexually abusing her for four years, filming her and others in the bathroom. The investigation uncovered 41 videos, including explicit content, which Rebbie had uploaded to his computer. He admitted to filming the girl specifically while undressed and showering. Rebbie faces charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. His preliminary hearing is set for May 1, and he is on a $500,000 bail. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family remains unclear.

Yûki Aoyama, a Japanese photographer, has created a series of images titled "Daughter and Salaryman" that depict teenage daughters with poised expressions while their fathers perform dramatic leaps in sharply dressed suits. The series, which showcases the fathers expressing their fun side and excitement, has garnered significant online interest despite little known about its origin. The images also feature the families posing in front of various Japanese landmarks, with some fathers adopting a pained expression during their energetic jumps. The daughters are seen in casual clothing, contrasting with their fathers' formal attire.

The passage discusses the return of Kevin Pietersen to Surrey ahead of the County Championship season, following his dismissal as England's managing director. Pietersen, who was controversially sacked in 2014, is now aiming to regain his place in the international set-up. The event at the KIA Oval, where Pietersen took pictures of photographers and joked with his team-mates, marks a significant step towards his potential reinstatement in the England team. The focus is on Pietersen's emotions and interactions during the team photo shoot, as well as the upcoming MCC University match.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to a poor run and a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, had been reinstated after initially being sacked. He replaced Florin Marin in January and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. The team is now 16th in the standings, six points away from safety.

Nabil Dirar, former teammate of Radamel Falcao at Monaco, believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, where he struggled after a serious knee injury. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been happier staying at Monaco, where he could have participated in the Champions League. Manchester United, however, is unlikely to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent due to his limited goal-scoring record during the loan season.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy, taking the till and approximately $1,500 in cash. The offender, captured on security footage in a fluoro orange sweatshirt, is described as very tall. No weapons were used, and the police are seeking public assistance in identifying the individual. They are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message the police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for a second time after being accused of having sexual relations with two underage students. The first arrest occurred on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, after which she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Granado was later arrested again for allegedly having sex with another 15-year-old student in her car on January 18 and 19. The second arrest led to her being booked into Irving County Jail and posting a $50,000 bail. The school district confirmed Granado was on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on school property. The exact plea Granado will enter for the second set of charges remains undisclosed.

A video showing a crocodile calmly swimming in Puerto Vallarta's marina with a dead pet dog in its jaws has garnered over half a million views. New Zealander Tim Weston witnessed the incident while on holiday with his wife. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, was curiously investigating the crocodile but was tragically caught. The crocodile held onto its catch for hours, causing a crowd to gather. Despite the shocking encounter, the crocodile was later seen in its sanctuary upstream. The incident sparked negative reactions on social media, with many expressing dislike for crocodiles. Puerto Vallarta, known for its mangroves and crocodile sightings, is experiencing increased human-crocodile interactions due to urbanization.

Steve Bruce, manager of Hull City, remains optimistic about keeping the team in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton and only six wins so far. With six games left, including challenging fixtures against top teams, Bruce believes that maintaining positivity and securing a few more results could help the team avoid relegation. The team's struggles are attributed to long-term injuries to key players, but Bruce is confident that they can overcome these challenges.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching after altering and asking pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewskesbury to change their SATs exam answers post-examination. The local education authority's investigation found that Guffick and some pupils changed answers outside exam conditions, leading to the annulment of the school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick admitted to the misconduct, which was deemed unacceptable professional conduct but not fraudulent. The panel recommended a two-year prohibition order, which was upheld by Education Secretary Nicky Morgan. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper for Manchester United, has not had much playing time since joining in 2010. Despite this, he has been enjoying his personal life, particularly with his wife Misse Beqiri, whom he married in a beach wedding in Mauritius in 2012. The couple, who have a son together, often share their life on Instagram, with Beqiri having over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard, who is third-choice at Old Trafford due to competition from David de Gea and Victor Valdes, has been linked with a move to FC Midtjylland but couldn't agree on a transfer fee with the club. Despite his struggles on the pitch, Lindegaard is content with his life off it.

Reggie Jackson, a Yankee Hall of Famer, purchased 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium in 1976 for an undisclosed amount. The letters, estimated to fetch $300,000 to $600,000, failed to attract bids at a Sotheby's auction, with only a Sotheby's employee bidding $260,000. Jackson, who attended the auction, humorously admitted he might have overestimated the letters' value. He expressed his wish for a new generation to own and enjoy this iconic piece of New York City. The letters were removed from the stadium in 2008. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their professional responsibilities after Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen smoking shisha pipes. Rodgers emphasized the importance of understanding what is acceptable for professional athletes and the impact of their actions on their responsibilities. Despite the incident, Rodgers has not disciplined Sterling or Ibe and aims to move past the matter. He also highlighted the inevitability of near-misses in sports and the importance of learning from them to progress. Steven Gerrard, who served a three-match suspension, is back for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Rodgers prioritizing the team's advancement.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal playmaker, returned to London after the international break and posted a picture with his dog, enjoying his home comforts. He impressed in the Euro 2016 qualifier where Germany beat Georgia 2-0. Ozil, who was signed from Real Madrid in 2013, will start against Liverpool in the Premier League. He has been performing well since returning from injury, providing four assists and scoring three goals. Ozil has adjusted well to English football, citing the frequent games and lack of winter breaks as reasons for his preference. Despite rumors of him being seen in a Berlin nightclub, Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger dismissed the claims.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed satisfaction with Luis Enrique's performance as the team's manager, dismissing rumors of a replacement. Enrique, who took charge last summer, is close to winning the La Liga title and has a contract until 2016. The team, under Enrique's leadership, won against Valencia in the Champions League, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed a new long-term contract worth around £100,000-a-week, running until 2020. This follows talks since the beginning of the season and is part of Brendan Rodgers' strategy to retain key players. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011, has been a standout performer under Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. His potential as a future club captain is evident, especially with Steven Gerrard's impending move to LA Galaxy. Henderson's contract extension also aligns with Liverpool's efforts to retain other players, including Raheem Sterling, whose talks are expected to resume in the summer.

Filipe Luis, a full back for Chelsea, has expressed his desire to stay with the club until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in signing him back. Luis has struggled to secure the left back position at Stamford Bridge but remains committed to Chelsea. The focus shifts to the Premier League title run-in, with Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, emphasizing the need for the team to maintain their focus and strive to win every game. Luis acknowledges the challenging nine upcoming matches but believes the team is prepared to handle the situation. Meanwhile, Luis has also played for Brazil in friendly wins against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes, a player for Wasps, had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North rescinded after an appeal. Initially shown a red card and suspended, Hughes's case was re-evaluated, and it was determined there was no intentional foul play. The incident, which left North unconscious and required him to rest from playing, sparked outrage and defense from various quarters. Hughes is now free to return to action but is not in the match-day squad for the upcoming Aviva Premiership fixture. The appeal hearing panel, led by Jeremy Summers, concluded that the incident was accidental.

Seattle native Tim Durkan captured aerial shots of a deep reddish sunset in Washington, caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The fires, initially started by farmers burning grass, were exacerbated by strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in intense red sunsets due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors. As the smoke dissipates, the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen and later found with red rims, detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook and decided to honor the man who found her car, Mick Sexton, by creating a smoothie at her restaurant. However, she also had to deal with the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana in the car.

Manchester City players face a £500,000-a-man bonus loss if they don't qualify for the Champions League, as they are incentivized contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. The team, currently in fourth place, is just four points ahead of Liverpool and must win a qualifying round to join the top three finishers who automatically qualify. The City squad has around £12million riding on reaching their European target. The team's season has been described as disintegrating, with seven losses including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League. Players like Sergio Aguero, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure could miss out on significant bonuses if the team fails to secure a top-four finish. The team's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, acknowledges the need for improvement after a series of losses. Manchester United, under Louis van Gaal, is confident in attracting top-class talent in the next transfer window.

In a'mini-derby' match between Manchester United's Under 18s and City, United secured their first victory with a 1-0 win. The game, held at Moss Lane, featured 13 English players, with 10 from Manchester. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a free-kick. The match, which was free to enter, showcased the skills and commitment of young players, with Marcus Wood and Marcus Rashford from United and Javairo Dilrosun from City demonstrating notable talent. Despite the victory, United remains two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both their matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series. The match highlighted the need for more first-team opportunities for homegrown talent.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon, who recently reached his 147th international cap, calling him a "legend of the game." Hart, who has represented his country 50 times, admires Buffon's performance at the age of 37 and sees him as an inspiration. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed his desire to continue playing well for his club and country, aiming to add to his own international caps.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant, has partnered with the Postmates app to enter the $70 billion food delivery market. The fast-casual chain will offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Previously, Chipotle turned down similar offers but has now approved Postmates. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services. Celebrity customers include Hillary Clinton and Florida senator Marco Rubio.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Martin Richard, are urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for the convicted defendant, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. They emphasize the emotional toll the case has taken on their family, including grieving for their son, battling injuries, and enduring surgeries. The Richards argue that the pursuit of the death penalty could prolong their pain and affect their children's future. They propose that Tsarnaev serve his life sentence without parole and waive his right to appeal, in exchange for the Justice Department removing the death penalty from the case. The Richards stress that their stance is personal and not representative of Tsarnaev's guilt.

A luxury Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet, costing £400million, has been custom-built for a mystery billionaire. The plane, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, has been transformed into a private residence with bedrooms, lounges, a state room, and a dining room with a private chef. The interior features a hotel-like ambiance with traditional rows of seats replaced by plush furnishings. The plane can accommodate several dozen guests, with eight full beds in the 'aeroloft' and additional seating areas for relaxation. The luxurious interior, complete with a conference room and over-the-top decorations, offers an exclusive flying experience far surpassing first-class on commercial flights. The layout and design of the plane have been meticulously planned to meet the owner's specifications.

SpaceX launched an uncrewed cargo spacecraft, Dragon, on a Falcon 9 rocket to the International Space Station (ISS). The mission also aimed to land the rocket stage on a floating barge, a first for the company. However, the landing was unsuccessful as the rocket tipped over after landing on the drone ship. Despite this setback, SpaceX plans to continue attempts at sea landings to reduce space travel costs. The Dragon will deliver supplies and return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo to Earth. This mission marks the sixth for SpaceX and the first by a private contractor to dock with the ISS. The launch was delayed due to weather conditions.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit, is located at the Westgate Hotel. A contest on NBC's Today show allowed an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding', which includes a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will marry on April 23. Elvis' former wife will be in the audience, and Priscilla emphasized that the wedding is not a joke, explicitly stating no impersonators will be allowed. Couples interested in this unique wedding must submit a video or photos with a compelling reason for their eligibility.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season, equalling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Despite a disappointing run against Manchester United and Arsenal, Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City, who are four points ahead in the Champions League race. The team secured a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, with Raheem Sterling scoring the opening goal and Joe Allen capitalizing on a defensive mistake for his first Anfield goal. Despite a strong penalty appeal from Newcastle, the referee did not award a spot-kick. Henderson emphasized the importance of continued victories and performances to close the season.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, moving provisionally four points ahead of Lazio. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a counter-attack, with goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making crucial saves throughout the match. The win was significant for Roma's Champions League hopes and filled the team with pride. Despite Napoli's extended winless streak, de Sanctis' performance was key in protecting Roma's three points. Security measures were in place due to a previous shooting incident, but the match proceeded without issues. Roma was missing key players Francesco Totti and Gervinho, but Pjanic stepped up to make an impact. Napoli had a penalty opportunity but there was no significant protest. Lorenzo Insigne made his return to the pitch for Napoli in the second half.

Doncaster Rovers experienced a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town in League One, resulting in a brief 27-second highlight video featuring only the kickoff, goal kick, and final whistle. The match, which lacked excitement, tested the patience of fans and posed a challenge for the media team to condense the highlights for the club's YouTube channel.

A man named Roland Giroux develops a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid fish, which he massages and interacts with daily. The fish, initially bullied by two other tank mates, becomes more sociable and enjoys the attention. Giroux feeds the fish by hand and notices its frustration when not played with daily. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid bred in Taiwan in 1986, swims around the man's fingers and towards the surface when he removes his hand from the tank, indicating its attachment to him. The video showcases the fish's calm demeanor during massages and its sadness when the man takes his hand away.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, faced challenges in Barbados due to a back niggle. Despite a year of ups and downs, Stokes has shown resilience and positive response to criticism from England coach Peter Moores. Stokes' aggression, if controlled, can contribute to England's success. The team aims to balance Stokes' natural exuberance with careful management, while also considering the potential role of second spinner Adil Rashid. England values Stokes' potential and seeks to nurture both Stokes and Chris Jordan to excel in the international game.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, sold out with a capacity of 33,000 attendees. The match is significant as Wales is in the best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup finals. Belgium leads the group due to a better goal difference, but Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has raised expectations for them to secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots. The Football Association of Wales has received a surge in ticket orders due to the buzz around Chris Coleman's team. Despite initial speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, Wales has opted for the Cardiff City Stadium, which they prefer over the Millennium Stadium, where they last played in a Euro 2012 qualifier in March 2011.

England's John Peacock has selected his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the Young Lions, defending champions, will compete in Group D with Holland, Italy, and Ireland. The team features young talents from Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. The squad will open against Italy on May 7, with subsequent matches against Holland and Ireland. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled after missing the Elite Round qualifiers.

Manchester City is interested in signing Belgian teenager Evangelos Patoulidis, a talented playmaker from Anderlecht's youth team. Despite interest from Barcelona, Patoulidis' family prioritized his education. City has engaged in discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation deal, as part of Manuel Pellegrini's strategy to secure future talent.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, having been strangled and beaten. The man responsible for her death was arrested but released on bail, with further questioning scheduled. Scotland Yard is seeking information from anyone who had contact with Santillan before her death. She worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and had expressed her love for these cities on social media prior to her murder. The investigation is ongoing.

Dawn, a woman who experienced seven miscarriages, was emotionally distressed after discovering that her friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, had stolen money meant for her unborn child's grave stone. The sum of £207 was set aside for a £500 gravestone. Despite her confrontation with Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, Dawn couldn't prove the theft. Jeremy Kyle's lie detector test revealed Jamie's guilt. The revelation left Dawn furious and betrayed, as she had intended to use the money to commemorate her child, Daniel James. After the show, Dawn broke down in tears, which were captured by the Jeremy Kyle cameras. Her partner, also named Jamie, comforted her following the incident.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group persecuted by the Sunni Islamist militant group, who were killed, captured, and displaced in northern Iraq last summer. The majority of the released were women and children, with the rest being ill or elderly. Arab tribal leaders coordinated the release, which was not immediately clear in its motivation. The freed Yazidis were sent to Irbil by the Peshmerga force. ISIS' brutal treatment of Yazidis, including reports of rape and enslavement, led to international intervention, including airstrikes and humanitarian aid. The Yazidi community, with a history of persecution, now faces the aftermath of ISIS' conquest.

Harry Kane, Tottenham's sensational striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. He has had an outstanding season, scoring 20 Premier League goals and featuring in a new animation showcasing his best goals and celebrations. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", highlights his achievements and is released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool's manager despite the team's third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher emphasizes that Rodgers' future should not be solely determined by one game and believes in the potential of the squad, especially with the right signings. Carragher, who has been recognized for his community work in Merseyside, hopes to inspire youngsters and give back to his underprivileged hometown of Bootle. He acknowledges the pressure on Rodgers but remains optimistic about the team's prospects for the next season.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, such as replica or model guns. The incident occurred when the toy, which fired sponge darts, was detected by X-ray machines. Despite his father Phil's criticism of the security officers' actions, James was forced to hand over the toy to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. Upon returning from their holiday, James received a new toy gun from eBay. The airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to send the original toy back to the family's home. The airport defended its actions by stating that passenger safety and security are their top priority.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, known as 'Rich', posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He outlined his ideal partner as someone who loves pets, enjoys outdoor activities, and is reliable, honest, and loyal. Rich, who is athletic, tattooed, and non-drinker, also mentioned he is not shy of spending on his partner and offers benefits like a gym membership and choice of phone and laptop. He emphasized that former partners are not welcome and all reasonable offers will be considered. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact Rich.

Greg Dyke, chairman of the Football Association, is supported by five former England managers in his bid to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. The managers, including Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Steve McClaren, and Sven-Goran Eriksson, warn that failure to back Dyke's proposals could hinder England's progress in the global football arena. They argue that the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking, and they urge support for Dyke's plan, which also proposes changing the definition of 'home-grown' players to those trained in England for three years before the age of 18. The managers highlight the emergence of young talents like Harry Kane as evidence that England can still produce top young players. However, only 36.8% of Premier League starters in the last round were eligible for England selection, indicating a need for more opportunities for young English players.

Demelza Poldark, portrayed by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now the mother of the show's latest baby, following a rapid pregnancy timeline. The announcement of her pregnancy in the previous episode led to fans speculating about a quick birth, with one tweet suggesting a new pregnancy could result in a birth within 10 minutes of the next episode. This contrasts with a previous pregnancy that lasted the full term between episodes. Despite Demelza's fast pregnancy, her relationship with Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, remains unconvincing to audiences, as Ross's feelings for her seem more dutiful than genuine.

Leicester City, under manager Nigel Pearson, is advised to concentrate on their own performance amidst a relegation scare, despite being three points away from safety in the Premier League. The team secured a crucial win against West Brom, with Jamie Vardy scoring an injury-time goal. Pearson emphasizes the importance of focusing on their own games and not being swayed by others' form, while also cautioning against over-optimism.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's travels included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale, despite being thought to be an endangered western whale. This discovery, made by scientists from Oregon State University, could indicate a need for further genetic studies due to the potential misidentification of western gray whales as eastern grays.

A landslide on Hokkaido Island's Shiretoko Peninsula caused approximately 1,000ft of seabed to rise to the surface overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline up to 50ft above sea level. The emergence, which was unexpected to locals, is believed to be due to melting ice and snow causing a section of land to drop. The land mass, measuring 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, did not cause any tremors or sounds. Authorities have not determined the exact timing of the landslide and do not expect further expansion. The phenomenon is not related to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Nepal. Marine life remains attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel, a player for Paris Saint-Germain, has denied rumors of his departure and expressed his love for the club. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc, van der Wiel remains committed to PSG and is interested in signing a new contract. The club is still linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves, but van der Wiel's decision to stay is not influenced by this potential transfer.

Carlos Tevez, a former Manchester City striker, is set to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus not expiring until 2016, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors is close to finalizing a deal for Tevez, but Juventus insists he must first end his contract. Tevez has scored 17 goals this season for Juventus and has previously scored 26 goals for Boca Juniors. His international manager, Tata Martino, believes Tevez's future in Argentina will remain unaffected by his move.

Pep Guardiola, Bayern Munich manager, ripped a hole in his trousers during a 6-1 Champions League match win against Porto at the Allianz Arena. The incident occurred amidst the excitement of the match, which saw Bayern secure a place in the semi-finals. Guardiola humorously mentioned he would need new trousers for the next match. The team's victory was aided by goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski, while Porto had initially led 3-1 but was ultimately defeated. Guardiola also discarded his suit blazer during the match.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in injuries to a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a five-year-old boy with chest pain, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries, and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. These patients were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. A man sustained hand lacerations, and two females remained unharmed. The crash scene was closed off, and diversions were set up south of Fernvale. Emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped individual. The highway was expected to remain closed for a few hours.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, comparing it to the fictional character Michael Knight from Knight Rider. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is set to start against Chelsea on Sunday. Arsenal, currently trailing Chelsea by 10 points, has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who has been out due to injury. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is the key to his potential in the Arsenal midfield. Wilshere's ability to stay fit is crucial for him to have a full season without long-term injuries.

Mark Clattenburg, a Premier League leading referee, will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Despite sending off three players from United and City this season, he has only issued two red cards, both to United players. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the match due to two bookable offences. Clattenburg's controversial past and the recent 2-1 loss of United to Crystal Palace add tension to the upcoming derby, which could determine the second place finish behind Chelsea. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

MP Bob Katter criticizes the Queensland Government for assuming Billy Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and hiding his criminal history. Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, has faced racist attitudes from major parties and sympathizes with Gordon. He defends his controversial statement, using the term "black puppet on a string" to describe Gordon's situation, citing his own experiences with racism. Katter also references other federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independent politicians becoming government puppets. He warns Gordon against making the same mistake. The statement has sparked social media criticism, with some questioning Katter's terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, uses dance as a means to inspire and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Despite facing bullying and being judged based on her disability, Dayna aims to show that she is just like everyone else, albeit with different abilities. She has created several videos, including one featuring her dancing to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off." Dayna's goal is to encourage others to reconsider their judgments and to turn any negativity into positivity. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area.

Orlando City, a Major League Soccer (MLS) team with a large Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. Hernandez, a Mexico international, has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid but remains a sought-after player. Orlando's interest comes amidst eight European clubs also vying for his services. Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to teenage midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has received interest from several European clubs, including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord. Pereira was on the bench during a match against Aston Villa.

Three individuals vandalized a white Dodge Charger at a South Los Angeles gas station by pouring gasoline on it and setting it on fire around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver, unidentified, was attempting to pump gas when the suspects, who tried to carjack him, lit the vehicle on fire. The incident, which was captured on surveillance video, resulted in the car's front end being completely destroyed. No one was injured, but the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson. The suspects remain at large. The driver's grandmother reported that the fire was ignited after the suspects attempted to carjack her grandson.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in southern Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite his misconduct, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. Manuel must prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing. His former practice has not been active for some time, and his practice addresses are listed on a residential street in Lamoni. Manuel has received three positive patient survey responses, each with a perfect score.

The United States lodged a complaint with Russia following an incident where a Russian fighter jet, an SU-27 Flanker, intercepted a U.S. reconnaissance plane, an RC-135U, in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea north of Poland. The U.S. crew deemed the Russian pilot's aggressive maneuvers and high speed as unsafe. The Russian jet circled the U.S. plane to identify it and obtain its tail number. The U.S. European Command refuted the claim that the U.S. plane's transponder was off. The Pentagon and State Department will file a diplomatic petition with Russia, marking this as not the first such complaint, with a similar incident occurring a year prior.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a parking lot at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama's visit. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was removed by breaking the rear right passenger-side window and using the momentum from another vehicle to break the case's handle free. The theft also included the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, but the weapon has not been recovered. The Secret Service was notified of the theft but could not comment on any increased security measures. Police found evidence of the theft, including skid marks and pieces of rope, but the hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The agent's bags and some clothing were found at a nearby Residence Inn. The motive behind the theft remains unclear.

Luigi Costa, a 71-year-old man, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in 2012. Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, which affected his mental state during the incident. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen found evidence of Costa's declining mental condition before and during the murder. The jury's decision hinges on proving Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa may have feigned memory loss during examination, but Professor Mullen refuted this claim.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended a penalty decision involving Ross Barkley and Leighton Baines after Barkley missed a penalty in a 1-0 win against Burnley. Barkley, who had not taken a penalty before, was given the opportunity despite Baines' proven record of 15 successful penalties from 16 attempts in the Premier League. Martinez supported Barkley's choice, stating that if a more experienced player like Romelu Lukaku had been available, he would have taken the penalty. Barkley's shot was saved by Burnley's Tom Heaton, but the team secured the win with Kevin Mirallas scoring the only goal of the match.

Two passengers on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico died in a suspected murder-suicide. The cabin was secured and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship departed Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day cruise and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cleaning staff found the deceased passengers after attempting to enter the cabin. The FBI and Puerto Rico Port Authority are investigating the incident.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced by winning 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw against Montserrat. Kluivert's team also won 2-1 in a match in Willemstad. He previously assisted Louis van Gaal in the 2014 World Cup and was a losing semi-finalist in 1998. Curacao will compete against Cuba in the next round.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan star, has won numerous European trophies throughout his career and considers helping Leicester City stay in the Premier League as rewarding as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's current struggles and being seven points away from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances. He believes that the team's determination and his own contribution can secure their Premier League status. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester in the summer and has quickly become a key player, is content with his time in the East Midlands and may extend his stay beyond his one-year deal.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children due to her unhealthy lifestyle of drinking and partying. She handed her children over to her mother, Debbie, at four months old and has since neglected them. Debbie, who has been raising the children, suspects Gemma of stealing, including an iPad, and has admitted to past thefts. Gemma's behavior has led Debbie to consider banning her from the house and from seeing the children, as she cannot trust her to care for them properly. Debbie loves the children but feels Gemma's actions are detrimental to their well-being.

Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored a goal against Manchester United after a strong challenge from Chelsea captain John Terry on United striker Radamel Falcao. Sky Sports pundits agreed that Terry's rough tackle was a foul, with Graeme Souness specifically mentioning an elbow in Falcao's head. Despite the goal's spectacle, the pundits felt play should have been stopped, and while Falcao could have done better to stay upright, Terry's foul was still deemed unpunished.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all on board were safely evacuated. The incident was captured by Michael Barnett, who posted the video to CNN iReport. The bus, which belonged to the country band, stopped due to a blown-out rear tire and subsequently caught fire after everyone had disembarked. The tour manager confirmed the cause of the fire. Hillary Scott shared a photo on Instagram, stating that the fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's other members were not on the bus at the time. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a scientist from Dundee University, is developing a laser system that converts sunlight into energy using satellites equipped with mirrors. The energy produced is then transmitted back to Earth, potentially making solar power viable in places like Scotland and providing instant power restoration in disaster areas. Unlike science fiction depictions, these lasers won't be powerful enough to cause significant harm. However, concerns about the control of these satellites have been raised. Meanwhile, Tokyo researchers propose a different laser system for the ISS to clear space debris, which is also not powerful enough for weaponization.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old predatory convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' for young girls, has gone missing after vanishing from a psychiatric unit. He was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who suffers from learning difficulties and is about 5ft 8ins tall with a heavy build and dark hair, was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He was convicted of this offence and other related sexual offences. Munden's case is significant due to the progression from non-contact to contact offences. A manhunt has been launched to find him, with officers urging anyone with information to come forward.

V. Stiviano, Donald Sterling's former female companion, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after Sterling's wife sued her. The lawsuit claimed Sterling used their money to buy Stiviano luxury items, including cars and a duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with Sterling giving her gifts and that she never exploited him. The court decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family and set a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill-gotten gifts. The gifts also included less expensive items like a costume, blender, and thong. Sterling's racist remarks and behavior led to his NBA team being sold and a ban from the league.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's recent transfer decisions and urged them to sign four key players - a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker - to win the Premier League title. He compared Arsenal's situation to Chelsea's previous season, where they struggled without these players but improved after acquiring Thibaut Cortouis, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa. Henry also questioned Arsenal's ability to win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first choice striker, despite his impressive goal tally of 14 in the current season. Arsenal, currently third in the league, is advised to follow Chelsea's example to secure a title win.

A young woman, who was abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn for years, shared her harrowing experience in court. Van Ryn pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who remains anonymous, expressed fear for her future relationships and struggled to understand why she was targeted. She had kept her abuse a secret until Van Ryn was caught, and since then, she has attempted suicide and suffered from depression since the age of 14. The young woman is concerned about how Van Ryn's actions will affect her future interactions with men. The hearing is ongoing, and those seeking support can contact Lifeline.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering from a serious knee injury that kept him out of the first team since March 2014. He has recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s and is feeling better with each passing day. Gnabry, who impressed last season before his injury, is now over his injury worries and looking forward to returning to the first team.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, tragically fell to his death after running from a taxi in Penarth, South Wales, to avoid paying the fare. The incident occurred after Phillips and friends, who had insufficient funds to pay for the cab ride, decided to evade the fare. Phillips leapt over a fence in the dark, leading to his fatal fall down a 70ft cliff. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, was unaware of the danger due to the darkness. Phillips' body was found the next day by a dog walker. The coroner ruled the death accidental, citing Phillips' disorientation and lack of awareness of the cliff's proximity. Phillips, who worked for Liam Gallagher's clothing label, had grown up in South Wales and studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham. He had returned to Wales for Christmas and was staying with his mother in Cowbridge.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the chaos. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed astonishment at the lack of compensation for the fiasco, especially given the agency's significant profit. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, resulting in a total payout of £203,066, with an average compensation of £92.68. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His recordings, such as the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, were highly acclaimed. Hogwood's academic background included studies at Cambridge University and he held various prestigious positions in music, including tutoring at Harvard University and professorships at the University of Cambridge and Cornell University. His passing was mourned by colleagues who recognized his generosity, influence, and dedication to historically informed music. The AAM continues to honor his legacy.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland decreased to 57 by the end of March, marking the lowest count in a 12-month period since 1976 and half the number from nine years prior. Sharp instruments, predominantly knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. While 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs, the majority had unknown status. Despite the decline in homicides, caution is advised due to previous revisions of figures and a rise in other violent crimes. The Scottish government and public services are urged to continue efforts to prevent violent crime and address irresponsible attitudes towards alcohol misuse and casual violence.

The Cherries suffered a 2-1 defeat to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking the first loss to the Black Cats this season. Despite Dan Gosling's early goal, the team failed to score in the match, contrasting their previous six goals against Hull. Coach Howe attributed the loss to missed opportunities rather than a lack of confidence, emphasizing the need to learn from the game and move forward. Sunderland capitalized on their chances with goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe, and maintained their lead even after Steven Pienaar was sent off.

Australian Prime Minister Mr. Abbott asserts that stopping boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea, as Australia detains migrants in offshore camps for resettlement. The New York Times criticizes this policy as "brutal," inhumane, and at odds with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Mr. Abbott also compares the Islamic State's actions to those of the Nazis, sparking criticism from the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, which highlights a fundamental difference between organized terrorism and state-implemented genocide. Despite the criticism, Mr. Abbott maintains his stance on stopping boats to prevent drownings.

Washington accuses Russia and the Syrian government of intensifying attacks on civilians in Aleppo, Syria, and suspends talks with Russia over the issue. The US criticizes Russia for failing to uphold commitments to cease hostilities and for targeting critical infrastructure and preventing humanitarian aid. Russia denies involvement in the deadly aid convoy strike and blames ground fire. In response, Russia regrets the US decision and criticizes the US for not fulfilling agreements to improve humanitarian conditions. The US also plans to withdraw personnel from a potential joint implementation center. Despite the suspension, the US and Russia will continue discussing counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

The Policy Exchange think tank proposes selling high-value vacant homes, estimated to raise £4.5bn annually, to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. This could create the largest social house building program since the 1970s, potentially reducing the social housing waiting list by half a million. However, Labour criticizes the plan, arguing it would displace low-income families and exacerbate the housing crisis. The National Housing Federation warns of creating new ghettos, while Labour MP Karen Buck highlights the reduction in the government's affordable housing building program. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off, citing new affordable housing initiatives.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old man from Swansea, died with a confirmed measles diagnosis, amidst a local epidemic of 942 cases. Despite the diagnosis, the cause of his death remains undetermined. His mother, Angela Colfer, reported that he had been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital before becoming unwell with a rash. An inquest is set to be held to conduct further tests. The family is unaware of how he contracted measles, as no close family members are affected. Since November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for the disease.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old man from Whitehaven, Cumbria, is charged with a historical offence involving an attack on a boy under 16 years old. The incident occurred in 2001. Hudson is scheduled to appear in court at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Guiseley and Gateshead are tied 1-1 after a tense match. Guiseley scored early on through a goal by Jake Lawlor, while Gateshead equalized with a goal from Wes York. The match saw several substitutions and yellow cards, with Gateshead's Derek Asamoah scoring the equalizing goal. The game ended with both teams sharing the scoreline.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Steve Lansdown, the majority shareholder, confirmed the club would begin work after signing a section 106 agreement, with a six-week wait for a judicial review period. If no judicial review occurs by March, the redevelopment plans will proceed in May.

Cuadrilla, responsible for shale gas fracking tests in Lancashire, has suspended drilling following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, marking the second such event in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is analyzing the data to determine if the fracking process caused the tremors. Fracking involves fracturing shale rocks to release gas, a method that has sparked controversy due to potential environmental risks. The BGS has confirmed that the process can induce earthquakes, as seen in the recent tremors near the drilling site. Cuadrilla has halted operations to consult with authorities and experts, with a decision on future actions pending the analysis. The Commons energy select committee supports fracking in the UK, emphasizing that environmental issues can be mitigated through regulation and good industry practices. The BGS continues to monitor the situation, with the latest tremor occurring 1.2 miles from the drilling site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for draping a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes during a performance in 2015. He was acquitted of two other counts by a jury. Carpenter, known for his charity work and busking, claimed the banner was a tribute, not a fundraising tool. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign's chairman confirmed Carpenter had permission to display the banner but not for collecting funds. Carpenter's sentencing is set for January.

Ipswich Town won 3-0 against Queens Park Rangers in a match where Luke Varney scored the winning goal. Ipswich had struggled in previous games, but this victory lifted them to 14th place. The match was marked by several missed opportunities and defensive errors, particularly from QPR keeper Alex Smithies. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy acknowledged the importance of the second goal, which set up their comprehensive win. Ian Holloway, QPR's manager, expressed disappointment and highlighted the need for mental toughness and solid defense. The match ended with Ipswich Town's strong performance, while QPR's record away from Loftus Road remained unchanged.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, performed impressively in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's progress, praising the elite performance environment created by the coaches that motivates the team.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive victory over Chinnor with a score of 29-12. The team's success was attributed to the strong performance of players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, who led the team with over 70 tackles each. Despite the win, Churcher emphasized the need for further improvement, as the team will face seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians in the next eight games. The Reds aim to build on their recent performance to avoid repeating the same results.

Nazrul, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, is alleged to have raped a 74-year-old nun, marking the sixth arrest in a series of attacks. The police arrested him at a Kolkata railway station after acting on a tip-off that he was returning to India. Eight suspects have been identified, with two still untraced. Nazrul was previously identified from CCTV footage and fled to Bangladesh. The attackers also stole money and ransacked the convent school. Milon Sarkar was arrested as the leader of the gang involved in the attack.

The passage discusses an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging, and Advertising in London. It highlights how technological advancements like the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports have influenced UK consumer purchases. The video also examines the evolving ownership and ranking of major UK brands. For those unable to view the video due to outdated browsers, a non-interactive version is available. Additional information can be found in linked articles about China's ownership, freezing food tips, and the BBC Good Food Annual survey on top UK consumer brands. The video is optimized for full screen viewing.

A woman in Stranraer lost money to a scammer posing as BT technical support, gaining remote access to her computer. The incident, similar to a previous one in Sandyhills, highlights the ease with which scammers can access victims' computers and the substantial sums they can steal. Authorities urge caution when answering cold calls from individuals claiming to fix alleged faults, emphasizing that legitimate organizations never request banking or account details over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with the third-placed Championship team, Featherstone. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, who previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford over 16 years, has replaced his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton. The Featherstone chairman, Mark Campbell, praises Duffy's accomplishments at Swinton and anticipates his impact at Featherstone.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic and a coastguard helicopter, responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. A rider suffered head injuries and hypothermia from lying unconscious on wet sand. She received treatment and was then airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to allocate a radio frequency for a global flight tracking system, addressing weaknesses exposed by the disappearance of MH370 in 2014. The new system will enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide through satellite reception of automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions. The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) aim to adopt new tracking guidelines by November 2016, including more frequent position updates. This decision was made to cover the current system's shortcomings, which leave about 70% of the world's airspace unmonitored.

Julian Hernandez, a missing boy since he was five, was identified as the long-lost child at age 18. His father, Bobby Hernandez, was arrested and charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity. His mother was notified of his recovery, and Bobby Hernandez is held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez of being involved in his son's disappearance around August 2002 when he claimed to be taking Julian to pre-school but then fled.

Firefighters were present at the Duncan Street site for several days after a blaze on March 2, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, run by Asset and Land Group, from accepting waste due to fire safety concerns. Despite being generally compliant with fire safety laws, the company must remove all waste and has until August 7 to appeal the EA's decision to revoke its environmental permit. The fire's cause is still unknown.

A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, focusing on Crimea's strong pro-Russian sentiment. The first bill would allow Russia to accept territories with a clear desire to join Russia, even if neighboring states don't sign treaties. The second bill would expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainian citizens, removing financial and residency requirements. The bills aim to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians amidst the conflict. Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea, indicating the bills' significance.

McLaren, a team with a storied history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline in performance. Despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Ayrton Senna, in the cockpit, the team's issues stem from the Honda power-unit. The team's slump began in 2013 due to chassis design problems, but they have since regained some momentum. However, they have faced scandals, including illegal possession of Ferrari technical information and misleading stewards, which led to fines and public apologies. The team's future success is uncertain, with team boss Ron Dennis expressing optimism that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again. However, the team currently struggles to achieve the high standards of their past.

Tommy Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and questioned by Merseyside Police. The shooting suspects had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour before the incident. A silver VW polo, believed to be involved, fled the scene and was spotted on various roads. Police are urging witnesses seen on CCTV to come forward, as their information could be crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to maintain a spiritual connection during Christmas, especially for those unable to attend traditional church services. It highlights Everyday Church Online, a virtual service platform that has attracted participants from 61 countries. The church has incorporated Star Wars themes into its sermons, emphasizing hope and humanity. Another approach is the fantasy game Guardians of Ancora, which encourages children to rediscover biblical stories. Additionally, creative digital content like the viral video "The Digital Story of Nativity" and the Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" are mentioned. The passage also notes the use of Manga to share biblical stories, with the Manga Messiah being distributed in multiple languages. Lastly, it mentions the use of social media platforms by religious groups to engage with their communities during the holiday season.

The Ebbw Vale eight-day hearing is evaluating a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with the Blaenau Gwent council offering 320 hectares as replacement. Experts dispute the claim that the development would harm habitats and plant life, with Natural Resources Wales finding it hard to determine the replacement land's value but not opposing the project. However, the Gwent wildlife trust disputes the developers' ecology report, which suggests a net gain in biodiversity due to habitat enhancement. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation before the Welsh government ministers decide on the project's future.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a Novaya Gazeta report on homophobic detentions and killings in Chechnya, claiming it insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The clerics warned of "retribution" against the true instigators, while the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy and highlighted the torture of detainees. Authorities, including Ramzan Kadyrov, denied the allegations. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses, amidst unclear details on previous reporter murders and accusations of Russian authorities' negligence. The LGBT Network is assisting victims to escape and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a company that receives housing benefit payments, partners with Fresh Start Housing, a charity that finds clients for single homeless men over 35 in London. The company and charity pass most of the rent to private landlords, resulting in higher total benefit payouts than the rent fee passed on to the property's landlord. Investing Solutions, set up by Samir Patel in 2002, is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, generating significant profit. However, the venture has faced criticism for allegedly housing tenants in unsuitable properties, with one tenant, Nigel McCann, having to remove 28 bags of rubbish to make a property habitable. Wandsworth Council, a major payer, has a team dedicated to ensuring the private rented sector is safe and affordable. Fresh Start Housing, with its own board of trustees, sources properties from private landlords and claims to house 788 homeless people since its founding. The Department for Communities and Local Government states that local authorities are responsible

Andrew Lawrence and NBA player Ben Gordon scored 14 and 13 points respectively for the GB team in a Eurobasket qualifying game against the Netherlands. Despite leading for most of the first three quarters, GB was overhauled by the Dutch in the last 10 minutes. The team's coach, Joe Prunty, emphasized the importance of completing every play and maintaining fire on both ends of the court. Prunty's strongest line-up was used in the final warm-up match before the six-game qualifying program. The Dutch team, led by Worthy De Jong, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter and won the game despite GB's comeback attempt in the last six minutes.
